TIGHT ON THE FACE OF A CLOWN
HE KILLED MY MOTHER, HE KILLED MY
HORNED VIKING HELMET AND FLOPPY COURT JESTER'S CAP

dialogues.speaker: A GLEAMING PORCELAIN SINK
dialogues.text: Bloody hands plunge beneath the water. They wash vigorously, with the thoroughness of a surgeon. Blood swirls down the drain, a great deal of blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now spotless, these hands -- soft, smooth and young -- adjust the cuffs of a black uniform tunic. Every move is quick, precise, efficient. Manicured fingers fasten a gleaming button. The hands rub out an invisible blemish on dazzling black boots. A stiff uniform collar is aligned. What little is seen of the face is boyishly fresh, clean-shaven and benign. The hands groom impeccable brown hair, position a uniform cap and pull away to reveal the grim death's head insignia of the Nazi SS. The TENOR SOLO SOARS HEROICALLY, but is silenced by a sudden COUGH. The COUGH BRIDGES a --

dialogues.speaker: AN OLD MAN'S FIST
dialogues.text: Five punishing decades have passed, and the hand that was once smooth and young has become a wizened fist. It covers the mouth of a man who hacks painfully. What can be seen of his face suggests advanced age. The skin is loose, deeply lined and alarmingly grey. The hand descends to a gleaming button. The top one, just below the stiff black collar. The hand grasps the button and slowly unfastens it. The tunic is folded and placed atop a pair of black pants. The SS cap drops onto the neat stack. Hear a BABY CRYING -- and a hushed DEBATE IN GERMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain falls heavily on this prosperous Bavarian municipality. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At town center stands Gunzburg's modest courthouse. The BABY'S CRIES and the HUSHED ARGUMENT CONTINUE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CRYING and ARGUING are LOUDER here. At the defense table Vashistha, a frightened young Pakistani, sits beside a fresh-faced assistant defense attorney named HILLMANN. Hillmann glances anxiously into the gallery where Vashistha's wife waits, tormented by the CRIES of her BABY -- whom she does not hold. Across the aisle, a social worker tries to quiet the WAILING INFANT who's sheathed from the waist down in a body cast. But the real action is taking place at the bench where lead defense attorney PETER ROHM, 40s, too-long blond hair curling over his collar, battles JUDGE and PROSECUTOR. Their German segues into slightly accented English:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You have no evidence. None. What's the point of dragging this out? The Prosecutor is a bitter old war horse.

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: The point, Counselor, is to protect the child from further brutality at the hand of her father.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Brutality?! She fell from his arms. Three witnesses agree it was a Simple accident --

dialogues.speaker: PROSECUTOR
dialogues.text: Of course they agree, they're all -- He breaks off. Peter turns to the gallery; the witnesses gaze back -- three dark-faced Pakistanis.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (quietly) They're all what, Herr Prosecutor? Intelligent adults? Trustworthy observers?... The shining future of the Fatherland? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge raises a hand in warning.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Counselor --

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (unrelenting) At least we can trust the doctor. As I recall... (a smile for the Judge) he's blond like us.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Herr Rohm.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (thunders) Defense moves for dismissal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has intensified. The courthouse doors swing open and the angry Prosecutor emerges, raises his umbrella and marches down the steps. The doors open again and the Vashisthas appear -- the baby asleep in her tearful mother's arms. They descend the steps. Once more the doors open and Peter and Hillmann emerge. They pause as Hillmann raises his umbrella. Peter watches his departing clients with satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (an_axiom) Always tell the truth, Felix. It's the greatest freedom we have. (and) Bet they didn't teach you that in law school. Peter tucks his own umbrella beneath his arm and strides into the rain, face skyward, getting happily drenched.

dialogues.speaker: DESKTOP
dialogues.text: Cigarette smoke and shadows. A bulging manila folder lies open on the desk, full of handwritten pages. Bony fingers dial a rotary telephone, number after number. Not a local call. The voice of the caller is heard, an aged man:

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ja. It's me... How are you feeling? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something slightly mocking in this voice. Something unwholesome. The fingers pick up a German passport.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ja, of course I have it. The passport is thumbed open to the photograph of its owner.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, no, you shouldn't worry... He's perfect. Catch a glimpse of the photo: a smiling Peter Rohm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daylight is waning as an old Volvo pulls into the driveway of this handsome two-story. The corner of a curtain flicks aside, as if someone inside is watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here he comes... Are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ja, ja, ready. Peter and Hillmann climb from the car and approach the house, Peter contentedly soaking up more rain. He pauses at the front door, the porch light dark something amiss. He tries the door and finds it unlocked, throws Hillmann a wary look, then pushes the door wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights flash on and a clamoring mob surrounds Peter, led by three figures: HILDE, a slight woman of 70, beating on a cast-iron skillet. This is Peter's mother. MAX, his father, a big, convivial man somewhere past 70, oompahing on an old tuba. And CORY, Peter's wife, a what -you-see-is-what-you-get beauty fiery enough to hold her own with Peter, snapping a flash picture. The crowd -- aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews and cousins -- shouts "Happy birthday!!!" Peter is delighted. These people clearly think a great deal of Peter, and he of them. Cory notes Peter's soaked condition with affectionate dismay. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Oh, Peter...

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (knowingly) Must have won another one. The PHONE begins to RING. Cory heads upstairs to answer it, calling over her shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Get out of those clothes -- you're dripping on my floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARTY NOISE filters up from below. Cory's on the phone. Peter approaches, towel draped around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (to phone) What's wrong with the quote? This morning you loved it. Peter leans in for a kiss. Cory playfully evades.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Of course he denies he said it. It makes him look like the money- grubber he is. Peter loops his towel around her neck. She ducks coyly out of the towel and stays with her call.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Paul -- Paul -- you know me better than that. He said it. If he didn't it wouldn't be in my article. Peter snakes his soggy arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I have him on tape -- want me to play it for you? Backed against the wall, Cory changes tactics, planting a quick but serious kiss on Peter. Then, with a crooked smile, she pushes him on his way down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: No, no, you've questioned my journalistic integrity, I insist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nieces and nephews play soccer in the rain. Sheltered by a veranda, Peter and the adults surround a table covered with gift boxes. Peter has changed into dry clothes and is modeling a ridiculous red plastic hat in the shape of a charging boar. Cory snaps his picture. At the far end of the table Max holds forth, Hillmann his captive audience.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: ... We had some neighborhood hoodlums who were always picking on this little Jew boy. (to Hilde) What was his name?

dialogues.speaker: HILDE
dialogues.text: (no hesitation) Herschel.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Herschel... I believe you're right.

dialogues.speaker: HILDE
dialogues.text: You know I'm right. The youngest of Peter's nieces, KAT, about 5 and completely overrun by the older children, appeals for aid.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Uncle Peter. Uncle Peter, fly me. Cory leans close and whispers to Peter. He grins and whispers back. Sharing lovers' secrets.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (removes hat; to Hillmann) A distinguished gift. I'll wear it tomorrow in court. Hillmann chuckles uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Don't laugh, Felix. He'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Uncle Peter -- With a war whoop, Peter leaps off the veranda into the rain. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Peter! He scoops Kat into his arms and charges after the ball, using her dangling legs to drive the ball past protesting defenders into the makeshift goal.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Scooo00000000000000re! !! Kat squeals with glee.

dialogues.speaker: ON VERANDA
dialogues.text: Peter rejoins the party from the house, toweling his hair, changed into another set of dry clothes.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (still rolling) He was walking home one day ina terrible rain, he must have been 10 or 12 years old --

dialogues.speaker: HILDE
dialogues.text: He was seven.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Seven... really? A fight like that?

dialogues.speaker: HILDE
dialogues.text: It was before we moved up on the hill. As Max thinks about that, Hilde hands Peter a card.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (conceding the point) Seven years old. He came upon those hoodlums bullying his little friend --and went after them with his umbrella. Max makes wild swashbuckling gestures, cackling at the memory.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: That afternoon when he walked in the house his umbrella was bent, his lip was bleeding, his clothes were soaked -- and he was laughing like crazy. (a proud nod toward his son) Because he'd won. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter finishes reading the card and looks up at Hilde, moved by its content. He gives her hand a quick squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mama. Only one unopened gift remains. Cory hands it to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Last one. It's wrapped as if for a child.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Cute. Who's it from?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You brought it from the office, didn't you, Felix?

dialogues.speaker: FELIX
dialogues.text: This is the first time I've seen it. Peter senses a joke.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Papa...

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Not me.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (the crowd) Anyone? His gaze settles on Cory.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I really don't know, Peter. It was in the house with the rest of the gifts.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Cowards. He digs in, tearing away the paper. As he lifts off the top, everyone leans forward with anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (playing the moment) Looks like... another hat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a flourish, he whips it from the box. Hilde draws a quick gasp. Max's jaw tightens.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: What in hell -- Peter sits transfixed. Holding the cap of a Nazi SS uniform. After a frozen moment, he reaches back into the box and pulls out a black uniform tunic.

dialogues.speaker: HILDE
dialogues.text: Dear God in heaven... Peter turns urgently to Cory.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You must have some idea --

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: No, it was just... here. No one knows more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearly everyone has gone. The uniform is spread across the table and Peter examines it under the light of a desk lamp, Max and Hillmann watching over his shoulder. Cory cleans up from the party, wanting nothing to do with this investigation.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Most of these uniforms disappeared in the last days of the war. The SS dumped them and tried to pass as Wehrmacht regulars.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (holding the tunic to the light) Look at the stitching here. See where the insignia should be? It's all been removed.

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: Why would a person do this, Peter? What does it mean?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Who cares what it means? Get rid of it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (a hooded look to Peter) Maybe something to do with Viktor Kohl.

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: . Viktor Kohl? No answer for that, except:

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Maybe someone put two and two together. Another look between Peter and Max.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: They used to stamp the serial number inside the collar... so they wouldn't get mixed up in the laundry. (to Hilde) Wasn't it the collar?

dialogues.speaker: HILDE
dialogues.text: (flat) The lining. Inside the left cuff. Hillmann raises an eyebrow at that as Max folds back the cuff and holds it to the light.

dialogues.speaker: LEFT UNIFORM CUFF
dialogues.text: As Max's fingers work the material, rotating it in the light, a set of badly faded numbers comes into view. Only four digits are legible: 4397.

dialogues.speaker: MAX, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There it is... what's left of it.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCENE
dialogues.text: Peter and Hillmann bend low over the uniform.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (reading, memorizing) Four three nine seven... four three nine seven... He strides toward the stairs. Cory turns in alarm. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Peter...?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I need to check a file.

dialogues.speaker: HORNED VIKING HELMET AND FLOPPY COURT JESTER'S CAP
dialogues.text: Perched together in shadow. Only the odd outlines are distinguishable in the room's low light. FOOTSTEPS APPROACH.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Peter -- what file? A light switch is thrown illuminating the colorless helmet and the dazzling jester's cap. The hats rest atop a file cabinet. Peter enters and bends over the cabinet, inserts a key and unlocks it. Bypassing the top drawer labelled "A-F," he opens the second one, "G- M," flipping through the files at the rear of the drawer. Cory watches uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Which file are you looking for? He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's gone. The sound of RAIN is prominent. Peter's gaze falls on the open window. He crosses quickly, feeling the wetness of the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did you leave this open?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: No, of course not... Peter looks out the window into the night.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Peter -- what have you done? When he doesn't answer, she urgently shuts and locks the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has stopped. A party is breaking up and teenagers, Heineken bottles in hand, move toward their cars. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Peter's Volvo pulls into the driveway of the house directly across from the party. Max and Hilde emerge. They pause at the driver's window.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Well... happy birthday, such as it was.

dialogues.speaker: HILDE
dialogues.text: Are you sure you and Cory wouldn't feel better staying here?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We're fine. Really. Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: HILDE
dialogues.text: I'm your mother. I get paid to worry. She reaches through Peter's open window and depresses his door lock.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (a smile) Good night. Max and Hilde walk to the house. Peter watches until they're inside before he begins backing from the driveway. Spotting a set of taillights approaching rapidly along the curb, he stomps on the brakes. Just short of the driveway the other car, a dark Mercedes, stops as well. Peter waits. There's room for the Mercedes to back safely past. It doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Come on. Come on. (calling out window) Go. But the Mercedes' lights go off. Exasperated, Peter resumes backing from the driveway. But just as he comes in line with the Mercedes, it reverses again.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (shouting) No! -- No! -- Watch where you're going! You're going to -- Laying on his HORN, Peter steps on his accelerator. There's no time. The Mercedes crunches against Peter's front fender. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (disbelieving) He hit me. Peter climbs out as the Mercedes pulls forward. Max appears.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: (calls) Careful -- kid's probably drunk. Peter approaches the driver's door. The Mercedes again pulls forward. Peter pursues -- but whenever he gets close, the Mercedes pulls further ahead. Not running. Just playing with him. Cat and mouse.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! You hit my car! Now he breaks into a jog, trotting alongside the car as it rolls forward. He reaches for the door handle.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You're in no condition -- The car's interior light snaps on and the driver is illuminated. This is no drunk teenager. He's in his late 80s, exceedingly tall and gaunt, clad in black, a skeleton with skin. MUELLER. For an instant he gazes into Peter's eyes, his face lit with perverse delight. Peter's grip on the door handle falters. With a DIESEL GROWL, the Mercedes pulls away. Peter sprints back to his own car.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Peter -- Don't! -- But Peter jumps inside and sets off in pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes focused on the distant Mercedes, Peter accelerates like a maniac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes catches the tail end of a yellow light. Seconds later Peter arrives to find the signal red and the intersection full of cross traffic. As soon as it clears, Peter gives chase.  14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes flashes past a manufacturing plant on the outskirts of Gunzburg. On one wall of the factory appears the company name in huge lighted letters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Volvo races beneath the towering evergreens as the Mercedes' lights disappear around a bend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter navigates the curve and looks ahead. The taillights have vanished.

dialogues.speaker: IN AN UNSEEN TURN-OUT
dialogues.text: The MERCEDES IDLES, lights off. As Peter's Volvo passes on the main road, the Mercedes' headlights snap back on, illuminating a muddy, rutted path into the forest. The Mercedes starts up the path. Peter veers onto the shoulder, pulls a U and comes racing back to the turn- out, sloshing off-road, tires throwing mud... until his car slews to one side and sinks to a halt, up to its axles in mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter pounds the wheel in frustration, watching helplessly as the Mercedes disappears over a ridge.

dialogues.speaker: ON PATH
dialogues.text: Flashlight in hand, Peter picks his way up the incline. He draws to a halt at the top, his way obstructed by a mass of barbed wire. Switching off his light, he takes in the wide clearing below. On the far side of the clearing a light glows from behind a low building.

dialogues.speaker: IN CLEARING
dialogues.text: Peter slogs through the maze of twisted gates and barbed wire pens, moving steadily toward the backlit building.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: stands dark and quiet. Peter peers inside. Turns from the Mercedes to the dark building. A wooden chute slopes up into its dismal maw. Light comes from within. Grasping the side rails of the rotting chute, Peter hoists himself upward.  15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge freezer doors stand ajar. Meat hooks dangle. And on the far side of this abandoned slaughterhouse, a gaping freight door opens onto a long platform. It is from somewhere on this platform that the light comes; in that light, indistinct shadows move. Peter eases toward the doorway. He arrives to the sound of MUTED LAUGHTER, followed by a sudden CRACKING, like the SPLINTERING OF BONES. He freezes, holding his breath. Waits. And waits. And waits. Then, summoning courage, he steps outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter stares into the light, unsure what to make of what he's seeing, his held breath slowly expelled. Before him, regally attired and seated at a small table spread with a linen cloth and set with silver service for two, is Mueller. A single parlor lamp shines over his shoulder. He's eating crab, CRACKING the SHELLS with gusto, bent over a thick stack of papers which he reads as he eats. Peter searches the shadows for danger before stepping cautiously into the light. Mueller cackles at something he's read.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Oh yes, well put. And finally he looks up, off-handedly, as if welcoming an old friend.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Peter. Good of you to come. (gestures to the empty seat) Hungry? Peter stands his ground.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: (with relish) I, Peter, am a cheat. Anda liar. A highly-paid perverter of law in the service of outlaws.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (flat) You're an attorney. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: (his smile) Like you. (then, as if it's a significant concession) You may call me Schmidt. Will that be acceptable? Or maybe Mueller. It's a good German name and less common than Schmidt. Would you like to call me Mueller?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Is that your name?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Is that my name? You make it sound so simple. Mueller smiles as if at a child then turns back to the papers.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: '27 October, 1982. Dear Frau Holtz, I have not yet received any reply to my numerous requests for an interview. However, I remain eager to discuss with you your former classmate -- Here he breaks off, sets the page aside and reads from another.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: '... Eager to discuss with you your former neighbor...' (and another) '... Your former student...' (and another) '... Your former colleague...' Etcetera, etcetera. He looks at Peter who has grown very cool.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I have dozens of letters like these, received by people all across Germany over a span of 15 years, yet always inquiring about the same man. Always seeking information about... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shrugs noncommittally ) ... acertain local celebrity. A hero of the last war. (lets that lie; then) They all bear the signature of a man named Viktor Kohl. Peter remains silent. The old man's gaze drops to Peter's untouched plate.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Are you sure you won't eat something? When Peter makes no response, Mueller takes the plate and dumps its contents onto his own. He eats ravenously.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: The letters bore as a return address the number of a post box here in Gunzburg. I came to Gunzburg to find Herr Kohl and ask him the reason for his interest... but the mystery only deepened. From beyond the circle of light comes an indistinct CREAK. Peter's eyes snap toward the sound.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: I found there was no Viktor Kohl. The name was a pseudonym -- a fiction. (pause) Who was he, Peter? And why was he hiding behind a falsehood? Another CREAK, as if someone has stepped on a loose board. Peter's eyes search the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Was he an enemy... or a secret friend? Or was he neither? Perhaps he was simply... confused... uncertain where his true sympathies lay. Peter bristles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Of course all this remained purely speculative until... very recently. (savors a bite) Oh, this... this is delicious. And, when he's good and ready, he slides his stack of letters aside to reveal a fat manilla folder.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Earlier today, in a home in Gunzburg, this file was discovered. And in the file -- copies of every one of Viktor Kohl's letters. He holds Peter in his unflagging gaze, a shark's smile spreading slowly across his face.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Peter, are you Viktor Kohl?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (right back) Are you Josef Mengele? Mueller laughs. And laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: You let your imagination run away with you. The good doctor drowned years ago. They have his bones, you know. The laughter subsides. Mueller's gaze darkens.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Why so many questions, Peter? Why this obsession with things past? His gaze bores into Peter, as if he is in some way assessing the man's worth. Though Peter makes no answer, Mueller nods.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Oh yes. You'll do. (extends his right arm in a sloppy salute) Heil Hitler. Mueller reaches casually to the lamp and switches it off, plunging the scene into darkness. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The SOUND of SUDDEN MOVEMENT. Peter's flashlight clicks on and finds Mueller's chair, now empty, then redirects, moving toward the lamp. Just as it arrives, there's a SHARP BLOW. A GASP. The flashlight drops to the platform. Then the flashlight is switched off.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK SCREEN
dialogues.text: The absolute silence of death. Seconds pass. Then BARELY AUDIBLE SOUNDS in the distance. Perhaps voices. And then, with the suddenness of an onrushing locomotive, the darkness comes alive with sound: VOICES, LAUGHTER, PUBLIC ADDRESS ANNOUNCEMENTS, all on top of one another, all too loud and somehow grating. Among the sounds:

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT P.A., (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Lufthansa announces the immediate departure of flight 964. Final boarding is now underway at Gate 15.

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Medical transport this way please.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Tickets.

dialogues.speaker: THRID VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'll need the patient's passport.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF DISTORTED IMAGES
dialogues.text: Light overtakes darkness. All is shrouded in thick fog, as if viewed through a film of Vaseline. Movement. The interior of an airliner. A stewardess. An IV bag hangs overhead. A glimpse of a white medical uniform. But then DARKNESS RETURNS as:

dialogues.speaker: PILOT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Flight attendants, prepare for departure. LIGHT AGAIN. Blue sky overhead -- and the hanging IV bag. The rear door of an ambulance swings open. A youthful FACE appears.

dialogues.speaker: THE FACE
dialogues.text: Comfortable? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A nice smile. The Face turns his attention to the IV apparatus, injecting something from a syringe.

dialogues.speaker: THE FACE
dialogues.text: Rest now. The world descends again INTO BLACKNESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sits in a straight-backed chair, red-rimmed eyes gazing vaguely ahead.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIOUS VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Frau Rohm? At length her eyes focus.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Have you talked to everyone at that party? Did you get a list?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIOUS VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We're working on it. She's battling an almost irresistible urge to wild panic.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Are they all accounted for? Did any of them own a dark-colored Mercedes?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIOUS VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We're checking. (then) Tell me about the missing file. What was the purpose of your husband's research?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (a distinctly unhappy memory) He was going to write a book. At a DISTURBANCE outside, Cory looks off sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cory rushes out. Two police officers are excitedly raising the garage door. They shine flashlights inside, illuminating Peter's Volvo -- the same car he abandoned stuck up to its axles in mud. It now rests in the garage, spotless, parked right where it belongs. Cory runs toward the car. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Peter?!!! But one of the officers turns from the car, shaking his head negatively. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE A CRAMPED, BEIGE CUBICLE
dialogues.text: A peculiar little room, not much bigger than a closet, viewed from an odd, CANTED ANGLE. MUSIC is vaguely audible in the distance, possibly an opera. Above, a bare bulb protrudes from an undecorated wall. To the side, a sink and bathtub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slumped like dirty laundry atop the commode, his head resting cock-eyed on the toilet paper dispenser. There's a nasty scrape above one eye. He squints groggily, lifts his head and winces. Finding a cotton ball taped to the back of his hand, he rips it away, examining a pinprick on the skin beneath. Then, staggered by a wave of nausea, he turns, groping to raise the toilet lid, and hangs there panting... homicide on his mind. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter rises unsteadily to gaze into a mirror. He steadies himself on rubber legs, gingerly touching the scrape above his eye. Moans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MUSIC is LOUDER here. Definitely opera. Something by Wagner. Peter sways down the passage into the main room of a simple house, where he turns an ungraceful full circle, taking in the austere furnishings. The only concession to luxury is a modest STEREO SYSTEM against one wall, the source of the opera. The room is in perfect order. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hello? His gaze fixes on the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A postcard-perfect scene. Rich green pasture land rises to meet a soaring range of glaciered mountains. A gravel road passes before the house and stretches away, empty as far as the eye can see.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter moves shakily to a stack of journals on a table, grabs the top one: "JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN COLLEGE OF ONCOLOGISTS." Beneath it is another journal, titled in Spanish. Another in German. He moves into an austere kitchen. He throws open cabinets and drawers, rifling them, looking for some clue to his whereabouts. He finds nothing. He pauses, OPERA BUILDING, his eyes wandering... He fills a glass at the kitchen sink. It slips from his unsteady grip and SHATTERS, soaking a countertop telephone and the directory beside it. The cover of the phone book catches his eye. He grabs the book. A cowboy is pictured atop a bucking bronc. Emblazoned across the photo: CALGARY, ALBERTA.

dialogues.speaker: ON PETER
dialogues.text: Stunned.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Canada? He sags against the counter, overwhelmed with nausea, pain and confusion. The OPERA has become UNBEARABLY LOUD. Peter lurches toward the stereo. He punches buttons. The MUSIC CONTINUES. He punches more buttons but the music won't stop. With a burst of anger he overturns the stereo, bringing the OPERA to an ABRUPT END. Breathless, he slides to the floor. Sweet silence. Out of the silence comes a sound. A HORSE'S WHINNY. Then another WHINNY and a MAN'S VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: His eyes fly open.  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter weaves onto the back porch. Ina stall built against the outside of a barn a mare paces in agitation. Shadowing her is a wobbly-legged foal. Peter warily approaches. The MARE WHINNIES. From inside the barn comes the voice of an old man, soothing and almost musical.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Easy, my mare. Easy. Through a window, movement catches Peter's eye. He moves closer to see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aged hands fill a syringe.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: moves to get a more complete view, but a water trough blocks his way. The hands disappear from the window. The MARE SNORTS and WHINNIES. Peter eases back toward her.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (ever calming) Be still, mare. Be still now. The voice comes from the stall. Peter tries to get a look, but the mare obscures his view. Only the man's tall boots can be seen.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Easy, girl... I won't hurt you. Peter climbs the rail fence surrounding the stall.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Baby's hungry. We need to get your milk going. With difficulty, Peter reaches the top of the fence. He teeters, fighting for balance. A losing battle.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE STALL
dialogues.text: Peter lands heavily in the dirt. At the sound, the foal skitters away. And suddenly he's seen: HEINZ BAUMGARTEN, in his eighties, dressed in simple work clothes and those tall boots, at the mare's flank in the process of injecting her with the syringe. In stark contrast to the sinister Mueller, Baumgarten appears grandfatherly and utterly benign. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He says to his visitor without any hint of mockery:

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Peter. I'm so grateful you've come. Then, with a peculiar kind of exuberance, the old man turns and disappears into the shadows of the barn. Profoundly unsettled, Peter follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the light of a grimy window, Baumgarten gathers bottles and syringes. From a distance, still muddled, Peter watches Baumgarten, something about this man rendering him momentarily speechless. And now Baumgarten turns. In his hand is a black leather bag. A medical bag. Peter's eyes lock onto it.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Surely, Peter, you suspected... even hoped... Baumgarten's gaze penetrates Peter.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Tell me it isn't so. The old man's sincerity is eerily compelling. Peter shakes his head, rejecting the impossible claim. His tongue is thick.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Josef Mengele is dead. I've seen his bones.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: You've seen bones. Yes you have. But not mine. And Baumgarten sweeps out of the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SQUEAKY FAUCETS are CRANKED ON. Water runs. A WAGNERIAN ARIA SOARS. Aged hands disassemble syringes and plunge them beneath the water, washing vigorously, with the thoroughness of a surgeon. A DOOR OPENS 0O.S.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCENE
dialogues.text: The STEREO has been righted. Peter enters. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Baumgarten cranks off the faucets and replaces the serum bottles and needles in the medical bag.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (all he can muster) Why... why are you...? Baumgarten stops his work and turns his full attention to Peter, exceedingly earnest.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Peter -- my friend -- I can't tell you how long I've wanted to bring you here. As my guest. All your letters. Your questions. I longed to answer. (beat) Please believe this was the only way. Baumgarten's words carry a peculiar seductive power, and in his befuddled condition, Peter fights their effect with difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: You searched for years, preparing to write the definitive volume on Josef Mengele. But you were never able to write it. Why? What questions couldn't you answer?... (then) Ask them now. Baumgarten reaches inside his jacket and extracts an airline ticket folder and a passport.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Or, if you're persuaded I'ma liar... or a madman... He places the ticket and passport on the counter between them.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: . Of course you're free to go. Peter stares at the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: After all you did to get me here... you'll let me go? Just like that? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Is that what you want? Peter regards Baumgarten... then the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter stands at the side of the road, clutching passport and ticket. Baumgarten watches from his porch, completely unruffled. A taxi pulls to a stop. Peter turns back for one last, bewildered look at Baumgarten then ducks into the cab. Baumgarten placidly watches his departure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glass doors part to admit Peter who surveys the busy terminal and heads toward a bank of phones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's daylight in Gunzburg, and Cory, looking drawn, is setting the breakfast table when, in another room, the PHONE begins to RING. She stiffens as Hilde answers.

dialogues.speaker: HILDE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Rohm house. A moment, then a GASP.

dialogues.speaker: HILDE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Peter!!! Cory races from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilde beams at Cory.

dialogues.speaker: HILDE
dialogues.text: It's him. Cory tears the phone from Hilde's hands, 36 hours of suppressed terror exploding in a frenzied blast:

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Peter?! Where are you?! Where have you been?! ARE YOU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the sound of Cory's voice, all of Peter's weariness, tension and confusion unravel... and he begins to laugh. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes. And, in spite of himself, all he can do is hold the phone and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sleeps in the window seat, blanket drawn loosely around him. A FLIGHT ATTENDANT collects an empty coffee cup. Beat. Someone passes on the way to the lavatory. Beat. A male passenger, too close to be seen in full, pauses near the sleeping Peter, then slips into the empty seat. Beat. The man takes hold of Peter's blanket, pulling it up, the better to cover him.

dialogues.speaker: P.A., (V.0.)
dialogues.text: In preparation for our landing in Berlin the captain has turned on the no-smoking sign. Please return your seats and tray tables to their full upright position. The Flight Attendant taps Peter's arm.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Sir? We're about to land. She moves off as Peter comes to consciousness and dutifully raises his seat back and closes the tray table. And finally, still a little bleary, he notices the man seated beside him:

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Dressed in a simple but immaculate suit.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: You missed the sunrise over Iceland... unspeakably beautiful. Peter jolts fully awake. For the first time facing this man with his faculties intact.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Tell me, Peter. The notion that a man should be considered innocent until proven guilty, do you accept it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (flabbergasted) What are you --

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Innocent until proven guilty -- do you accept it?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Of course I accept it. Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: And this man Mengele -- what do you think of him? Peter looks at Baumgarten as at a crazy man. answer is immediate.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What do I think of a doctor who butchered hundreds of thousands? I think he's burning in hell.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: You condemn him... though no court convicted him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No court had the chance. Or ever will. (pointedly) Because he's dead. I've studied the remains myself. Baumgarten is unflappable, his tone mildly condescending.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: You've studied the remains. Are you a forensic scientist, Peter?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'm an attorney. I know how to evaluate evidence.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Then evaluate the evidence before your eyes!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What evidence? An old man with a doctor's bag? (MORE )
But his (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then) When I first heard that Mengele's grave had been found I refused to believe it. It was unthinkable that the Butcher of Auschwitz had escaped justice. I checked every shred of evidence, determined to find the mistake. (shakes his head) But there was no mistake. The evidence was absolute. Absolute. (a burning look) So stay the hell away from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first passenger off the plane, Peter strides up the jetway, distancing himself from the madman behind. CAMERA MOVES WITH him as he emerges into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's blinded by the glare of intense lights. A voice cries out:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There's the attorney! A jumble of television lights, cameras and microphones extends toward him. Voices shout questions. There's a fleeting glimpse of the predatory Mueller. Then Hillmann, frantic, emerges from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: Peter, I got your fax.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: . What fax? Didn't you talk to Cory? And then her voice, almost lost in the din:

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Peter!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (straining to find her) Cory?! Separated from him by the phalanx of reporters, she struggles to get through. But the reporters go wild with cries of: "There he is!" "Is that him?" "Will you talk to us?" Peter's up on his toes, trying to keep Cory in sight, when a hand fastens firmly around his elbow. He whips a look to his side to see:  30.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: He holds Peter in a surprisingly strong grip and steps forward with Peter involuntarily at his side. Baumgarten smiles shyly and speaks into the outstretched microphones:

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Thank you. I... (waits as the crowd falls silent) As you know, I am Doctor Josef Mengele. The press erupts in a torrent of questions. Baumgarten turns to Peter and declares over it all:

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: And this good man, Herr Peter Rohm -- has agreed to represent me at trial. Peter goes white. He shouts to the press:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, that's a lie -- I_AM NOT THIS

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: Men wearing the crisp uniform of the German Federal Police move in fast, led by Federal Prosecutor HORST VOIGT, a big, gruff man in his 50s.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: What are you doing in the middle of this, Rohm?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, Horst, I had nothing to do -- But the federal officers surround Peter and Baumgarten and sweep them side by side through what has turned into a near-riot. Peter struggles vainly to separate himself from Baumgarten, his eyes searching wildly for Cory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is stuffed into a dark Mercedes sedan. Baumgarten is pushed into another, a heavy armored limo with black- out windows. The cars pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter's sandwiched in back between two officers, furious at his predicament. Up front, Voigt flips briskly through: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Argentine passport dated 1956, in the name of Josef Mengele. Paraguayan passport dated 1959, issued to 'Jose' Mengele. Lab notes from Auschwitz bearing Mengele's signature. (looks to Peter) This package didn't come from you?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I've never seen those documents in my life.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: (waves fax) And I don't suppose it was you who notified the press.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Horst, I was kidnapped!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The speeding convoy turns into a large university hospital near the city's center. Men spill from the cars, whisking Baumgarten into the building. Peter pauses at the car door, laying a hand on Voigt's arm.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Please, Horst -- All the times we've faced off in court... I give you my word: Whatever game that old man's playing, I'm no part of it. (his plea) Send me home.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Did you miss that little show at the airport? Whether you know it or not, you are a part of it. And until I prove Baumgarten's a fraud, neither of you is going anywhere. Two formidable officers move in on either side of Peter. OVER this, the monotone of an interrogator:

dialogues.speaker: INTERROGATOR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: State your true name.  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baumgarten sits before a roomful of investigators as the uninspired INTERROGATOR reads from a list of questions. Peter and Voigt listen from the rear of the room.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: My name is Josef Mengele.

dialogues.speaker: INTERROGATOR
dialogues.text: State your father's name.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Karl Mengele.

dialogues.speaker: INTERROGATOR
dialogues.text: Mother's name.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Walburga Mengele. Baumgarten answers easily.

dialogues.speaker: INTERROGATOR
dialogues.text: The name of your first wife.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Schoenbein. Irene Schoenbein. My family didn't care for her. Too Protestant. Too... strong- willed. Baumgarten smiles at the memory. Convincingly authentic as an aging gentleman reminiscing about a lost love. Peter applauds, slow and loud, impossible to ignore.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Congratulations. A-plus. You did your homework. The attention of the entire room turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: If you have something to say, Rohm, say it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Of course he knows the answers. What did you expect? We're not dealing with children.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Oh? Who are we dealing with? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Who benefits by opening these old wounds, by putting Germany at war with itself? Old Communists from the East? Old fascists? New fascists? Look out the window, Horst. There's someone out there -- using us.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Who? Tell me. Who?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Any of a hundred groups. I don't know. I only know that's the question we should be asking -- not the name of Josef Mengele's mother. Voigt is thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: We must tread carefully here. Serious allegations have been made. This investigation must pursue all avenues until we find irrefutable proof that this man is a fraud.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We already have proof -- the DNA, the dental records, the bones -- Baumgarten breaks in, his voice clear and commanding.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: The bones, as you call them, belonged to my cousin Gerhard Sladkey. He drowned while swimming in Brazil. (beat) He was similar to me in appearance.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Similar? Same height, same dental records... same DNA? Baumgarten reaches inside his suit coat and extracts a yellowed envelope. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Gerhard was, for reasons of his own, living discreetly in Sao Paulo. After he drowned, friends buried him at Embu, then broke into my dentist's office and traded his records for mine. Then, at the right moment, with my pursuers closing in, these friends led police to the grave of Josef Mengele. The chase ended. (beat ) Gerhard was a close enough relative that his DNA made a convincing match. He forcefully extends the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: These are the dental records of Josef Mengele. (and) Ask me anything. I'll answer any question you like. Peter ignores the envelope, unmoved by this tale.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Don't be an idiot. Ask me. ASK ME.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Tell me this. Why would a man who spent fifty years running for his life suddenly just... turn himself in? The question seems to please Baumgarten. His words come laden with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: The Jews... the Jews say I mutilated their women, they say I cut their children to pieces. The Butcher of Auschwitz they called me. (roars) But I am not a butcher. NO!!! (quietly) I am a physician... a man of heart... a man of compassion. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A man of compassion who mutilated women and cut children to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Is a surgeon a butcher because he cuts with a knife? Because he finds a diseased limb and removes it to save the whole body? (fiercely) That isn't butchery, that's medicine. Peter's eyes narrow infinitesimally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A) Baumgarten lies on his back as technicians position an X-ray apparatus above him. B) A technician positions calipers alongside Baumgarten's skull, measuring the span between his temples. Cc) A brigade of INVESTIGATORS works a bank of phones.

dialogues.speaker: RED-HAIRED INVESTIGATOR
dialogues.text: Baumgarten, right. What date do you show him entering the country?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND INVESTIGATOR
dialogues.text: Everything we know. Bring every last file. I've already spoken to the ambassador. D) A team of photographers positions Baumgarten. A strobe flashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His cadaverous face in shadow, Mueller gazes at something or someone unseen. He extracts a cigarette and lights it, inhaling deeply.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Well? Another long drag on the cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Welcome home, Herr Doctor. Mueller bares his yellowed teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door flies open and Peter emerges, disgusted. He steps across the corridor and throws open a window, allowing the night air to wash over him. Mueller steps through the doorway, flashes Peter his sharkish smile and strolls away. As he goes, Mueller passes a long line of aging men and women seated uncomfortably along the wall. Voigt steps from the shadowy room.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Katarina Meissner. FRAU MEISSNER, a stalwart old woman devoid of emotion, trundles into the room. A commotion arises at a security checkpoint down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: COMBATIVE FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: The prosecutor approved it!!! Let_me through!!! Peter turns.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Cory?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Peter!!! She pushes past the security men, rushes to Peter and throws her arms around him. They hold one another ina ferocious embrace. Kiss.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Oh, Peter -- She leans back, inspecting him, soaking him in. He's here. He's real. He's alive. She sees the scrape above his eye.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: What did they do to you?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's a bump. It's nothing. Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I am now. He ushers her to an unoccupied bench.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Peter -- the fight I had to get in here. What's going on? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Baumgarten madness. And Voigt is taking it all seriously. (his frustration) All they need is one discrepancy -- one tiny detail that doesn't match. Which gives her pause.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: And what if... what if they can't find anything?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: They will. And then we're going home. Frau Meissner steps from the room, in her eyes the terror of having seen a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: FRAU MEISSNER
dialogues.text: No, no. No, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: (emerging behind her) Frau Meissner --

dialogues.speaker: FRAU MEISSNER
dialogues.text: That_man_is not our Josef! She flees down the hall, leaving Cory profoundly unnerved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A convoy moves with police escort through the historic government district to the Justice Ministry. Baumgarten is moved under heavy guard into the building. Voigt supervises, ignoring the shouting Reporters.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTERS
dialogues.text: (overlapping) Herr Voigt, over here!/It's been a week -- why the delay?/Is it true a decision will be made today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dozens of experts around a long table, at the head of which stands Voigt. Photographs of two handwritten documents are projected on a large screen. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH ANALYST
dialogues.text: . Note the minor differences in loop width, here and here -- noticeable yet consistent with the normal evolution over time of an individual's --

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Professor, please. Your conclusion.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH ANALYST
dialogues.text: (a beat) If this is a forgery, it's the best we've ever seen. Voigt turns to another of the assembled.

dialogues.speaker: GENETICIST
dialogues.text: We have no genetic sample from Mengele himself. Period. So we're forced to rely on relatives. All we can say is that the subject is related in some way to the Mengele family -- with a genetic match roughly comparable to that of the Embu remains. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Dental records.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER EXPERT
dialogues.text: We're still checking but so far his story about the cousin holds.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Professor Krill. The screen behind Voigt lights up with two new photographs, one of Josef Mengele as a fresh young SS captain, the other a current likeness of Heinz Baumgarten.

dialogues.speaker: KRILL
dialogues.text: The purpose of this exercise is to compare measurements taken between fixed points on each face, looking of course for any detectable differences. 38. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ghostly 39.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: And what differences did you detect?

dialogues.speaker: KRILL
dialogues.text: Well, of course I didn't detect any or we'd all be home now, wouldn't we? (then) Watch this. X-ray image of a skull separates from the photo of Baumgarten and glides into the space between the photos. The X-ray

dialogues.speaker: KRILL
dialogues.text: An X-ray of Baumgarten's skull... Now we overlay it. image floats toward the youthful photo of Mengele, overlapping until it achieves a perfect match. Peter stares at the screen. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: We launched this investigation believing it would last fewer than 24 hours. And yet one week later -- here we are. (a beat) In the face of the evidence we've seen, can any one of you make a persuasive case that Heinz Baumgarten is not in fact Josef Mengele?

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: A decision must be taken. We try this man as Mengele or we let him go.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER VOICE
dialogues.text: Herr Prosecutor, please, we're moving too fast.

dialogues.speaker: AND ANOTHER
dialogues.text: What about the Embu remains? The evidence for Baumgarten is no better than the evidence for the bones.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: No better -- but also no worse? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A reluctant MURMUR of ASSENT.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Then I ask you: what choice do we have? Peter sits stock still, unblinking, his imagination ablaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voigt leads a troop of officials to a guarded, unmarked door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baumgarten looks up as the door is thrown open and officials flood in. He rises, eyes dancing with anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Hauptsturmfuhrer Josef Mengele?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: (crisply) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: It is my duty to place you under arrest for war crimes, for crimes against minorities, and for crimes against humanity. Handcuffs are snapped into place. Baumgarten, greatly satisfied, surveys the crowd... looking for someone who isn't there. He's whisked from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving under heavy guard.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Where is Peter Rohm? The company descends a staircase.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Peter Rohm -- where is he? Has he been released? They move through another corridor, stopping before a steel-reinforced door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: I_demand to see my attorney. The door is unlocked and he's led into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where he's uncuffed. Before he realizes what's happening, the officials withdraw and lock the door, leaving Baumgarten disoriented in the shadowed cell. He pounds the door and rages:

dialogues.speaker: PETER ROHM
dialogues.text: Baumgarten falls back from the door. For the first time, he looks old and tired and perhaps a little bit frightened. And that's when Peter steps from the shadows .

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'm not your attorney. (beat ) I've been released. I'm leaving Berlin. Recovering his equilibrium with astounding speed, Baumgarten turns.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: How nice for you. Why are you still here?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'd like an answer before I go. Why me? Baumgarten considers.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: I like my question better. Baumgarten crosses to a simple bed where he removes his suit coat and folds it with precision.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: You're a starved fish, Peter. Circling the worm. Longing to bite but terrified that inside you'll find a hook. Am I Josef Mengele... or am I not? You don't know. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Peter turns for the door. Calls.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Guard!

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: And if I am Mengele, what then? Will you swim away, little fish? (right at Peter) You're incapable of it or you'd be gone already. Peter turns back. Outraged.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You broke into my home, you kidnapped me, you slandered me in front of the world. Baumgarten steps to an exposed toilet where he tears off a length of toilet paper and folds it into a neat pad.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: I'm a sick old man. I do nothing. Baumgarten dampens the pad of toilet paper and begins polishing his shoe. Peter raps loudly on the door.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Guard! The door opens.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Why you, Peter? Peter waits.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Because you're Germany's most eminent attorney? Not at all. Did you think I needed you to -- what -- defend me? (emphatic) I_don't want it. You hear me? I want no defense. Peter waves the guard off. The door closes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why then? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: You were selected for one reason only. You're known to be that rarest of creatures. An honest man. Finished with the first shoe, Baumgarten polishes the other, taking an intimate tone.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: I'll tell you a secret. I've come to tell my story. To tell it all. Exactly what I did at Auschwitz and why. A thing that's never been done. He finishes the second shoe and straightens. He speaks with dazzling intensity.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Help me, Peter. Help me tell the truth.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Josef Mengele doesn't return after fifty years to make a confession.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: To tell the truth. Baumgarten cranks on the water and vigorously washes his hands. He cranks

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What truth? The selections? The gassings? The butchery in the laboratory?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: The truth! (exuberantly) I deny nothing! I'm ashamed of nothing!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You would take responsibility for all those crimes?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Crimes, Peter? Crimes? off the faucets and turns, holding his wet hands high like a surgeon who's just scrubbed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: We'll have to see about that. Peter is repulsed by the magnitude of this man's perverse arrogance. He reaches for the door.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Naturally you have a great deal to consider. So many loved ones. You don't want to bring harm to any of them. Peter's jaw tightens.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Only that you have a great deal to consider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quitting time. The elevator descends, packed with departing workers. At the rear of the elevator stands Peter, bone tired and shaken to his core.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors slide open and passengers exit. Peter is the last to step into the lobby. A woman's arms encircle him.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Peter. He wraps her in a fierce embrace.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Oh, thank God. They really let you go. He pulls her toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Peter. We need to call home. He sees her face. Stops. Something's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Your mother called. They can't find your niece Kat. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Peter's blood freezes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Little Kat? He reaches for his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: She and the boys were at the soccer field. They all ran home but Kat never got there.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (dialing) How long ago was this?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I don't know, a couple of hours. When I talked to your mother, they were checking with friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max picks up the RINGING PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Rohm house. A police officer crosses the room behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Peter! (and) No, no, false alarm. Everything here is wonderful. FOLLOW the police officer TO the next room where Peter's sister clutches 5-year-old Kat.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: She's back... No, it was stupid, really. She got lost on the way home and a young man helped her. He drove her around until she saw a house she knew. Ja. Brought her right to our door. The officer speaks to Hilde. She signs a paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter hangs up. Tells Cory: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She's fine. She's home. It was nothing, completely innocent. Words he has difficulty believing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: News crews press in around Peter, shouting questions as he and Cory exit. Ignoring them, he pushes forward. In the street a car passes, the young men inside shouting, hooting and waving an Imperial German flag. Peter turns back to gaze darkly at the upper floors of the old building. Wondering. He finally allows Cory to pull him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Cory move in a line of passengers through the airport security check. Peter's quiet, his mood dark. Cory watches him uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I was afraid you would decide to stay.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (beat ) Why would I do that?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: To do what you've always talked about. Find out what turned our neighbor into a butcher. Peter says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Peter -- if that man is Mengele, he was our neighbor by accident. He has no connection to us.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I keep trying to believe that.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: And now you're going home. She kisses him on the cheek. A quick, sweet kiss full of gratitude and relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter stands at a urinal. When he finishes, he turns and crosses to a row of sinks where a knot of men is gathering around something taped to the mirror.  47.

dialogues.speaker: A PHOTO BLOW-UP
dialogues.text: Peter's niece Kat. She's surrounded by a half-dozen young men, their faces cropped from the photo but their arms raised in obvious Nazi salutes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: shoves through the group, rips the photo from the mirror and studies it in fury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cory looks up from a newspaper as Peter returns. One look tells her something is desperately wrong.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Fog shrouds the ancient stone towers and soaring ramparts. Across the road, Peter climbs from a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Official notices and warnings adorn the walls at the entrance to this federal facility. Armed police guards swing open the giant door to admit Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stone walls are hung with medieval tapestries. Down the center of the room extends a long wooden table. Peter sits stiffly on one side, waiting, until a door opens and guards shepherd prisoner Baumgarten in. He sits opposite Peter. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Miss your plane? Peter slaps a legal pad on the table, trembling with rage.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Josef Mengele on multiple occasions injected dye into the eyes of unsedated prisoners. Did you inject dye into the eyes of unsedated prisoners? Beat. Then, as if the question had never been asked: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: How familiar are you with the medical habits of the Dutch? Peter repeats, hard and cold:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did you inject dye into the eyes of unsedated prisoners?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: I'll happily catalogue my experiments for you. But it's the Dutch physicians we must --

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (overriding) Josef Mengele kept the eyes of deceased prisoners pinned to a board like butterflies. Did you keep such a board? Baumgarten remains genteel.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Medical studies often require the collection of specimens. Now please listen. Medicine in the Netherlands --

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Josef Mengele personally selected up to 400,000 men, women and children for death by gassing. Did you select these individuals for death? Baumgarten regards Peter with his own quiet fury.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: I thought you wanted to understand.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did you select these individuals for death? (and again) Answer the question: Did you select these individuals for death? And finally it comes, an explosion: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERYTHING
dialogues.text: The ferocity of the outburst silences Peter. Baumgarten stands.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Walk with me. A faint, almost subliminal sound begins, a SLOW, THROBBING HISS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fog hangs thick atop the high wall where Peter walks uneasily with Baumgarten in the fading light, shadowed by a trio of guards. The HISS is louder.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Do you know, Peter, how many doctors staffed Auschwitz?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Not the exact figure. Five. Six.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: The exact figure is 22. Myself... and 21 others.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How many of those others volunteered for duty at Auschwitz? How many met arriving trains to perform selections on their days off? How many others did it sober?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Medicine is hard work. Not everyone has the stamina. Baumgarten turns down a narrow stairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A courtyard within the fortress. The disquieting HISS BUILDS.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Are you familiar with the work of Karl Bindong and Alfred Hioche? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter isn' 50. t. And can't fathom its possible relevance.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Physicians. Years before Hitler, they wrote a book they titled The Permission to Destroy Life Unworthy of Life (an assignment ) Read it before we meet again. Before Peter can protest: They near the place

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Bindong and Hioche saw incurable patients, suffering patients, patients whose lives had lost all meaning. To these patients, the physician offered nothing but prolonged misery. a compact citadel at the center of the ward, of last defense. The RHYTHMIC HISS seems to emanate from within.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Unless -- and here is the book's genius -- unless the physician abandoned the slavish pursuit of life for life's sake and instead granted these patients release. (beat ) Sometimes, argued the authors, ruled by mercy and compassion, the physician must kill. Baumgarten reaches the entrance to the inner citadel. He turns toward Peter. Peter can'

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: In the days before the war, everyone in German medicine understood this. t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That's your defense? Auschwitz as popular medicine? You're insane. I've known medical people from those years who never accepted -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: (overlapping) Oh, you've known people? Who have you known?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Individuals of principle. Individuals inalterably opposed --

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: who?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (combative) My mother for one.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Your mother was a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A nurse. At the Wuerzbach Children's Clinic in Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: (astonished) The Wuerzbach Children's Clinic... really? (slow, secret smile) Well ask her. I'm sure she can tell you. With startling vitality Baumgarten shoves open the heavy door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eerie relic filled with deep shadows. The THROBBING HISS is much louder here. Baumgarten hastens forward.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (provoked) My mother worked for 30 years at a school for the mentally handicapped --contributing to lives your book would have dismissed as meaningless.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: (a look back; caustic) Do you think I invented Auschwitz? Is that what you think? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All the tissue samples I collected -- where do you think they went? Who do you think funded my research? They've arrived at a narrow stairway. Baumgarten plunges downward. The THROBBING QUICKENS.

dialogues.speaker: ON STAIRWAY
dialogues.text: Peter follows Baumgarten down. With every step, the menacing THROBBING INTENSIFIES.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You maintain that everything Mengele did at Auschwitz was a function of mercy and compassion.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Without exception.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The work of a dutiful physician.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Yes, Peter. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (hard) Explain Greta Holtz. Baumgarten's eyes narrow. He can't place the name.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: At the railroad siding. She was selected for gassing. Baumgarten searches his memory.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She didn't cooperate. Before them now, all has become utter blackness. The HISS is now a ROAR. Peter must shout.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She wouldn't stay on the truck. Josef Mengele would remember. Baumgarten looks up sharply. At that instant, the ROAR CRESCENDOS and an enormous black mass THUNDERS out of the darkness, blowing dust and soot all around them -- a mountainous steam locomotive scarcely an arm's length away. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A string of decrepit CATTLE CARS follows. Between the cars, flashes of light are seen. The last car passes and a grim scene is unveiled across the tracks: halted on a siding, a train disgorges a procession of ragged passengers. Shouting soldiers herd them toward a raised platform. Atop the platform stands a young SS officer, polished cane in white-gloved hands. Josef Mengele. Peter and Baumgarten remain visible in f.g. as passengers are made to pass before Mengele, who divides them into two groups. The group on his left is crowded onto open-bed trucks. Mengele is distracted by a disturbance that has erupted around a young woman who resists as soldiers force her onto a truck. Once aboard, she climbs over the side and drops back to the ground. Soldiers surround her.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Mengele had selected her for death. She resisted. He was outraged. Baumgarten watches as young Mengele leaps down from his platform and, with the back of his white-gloved hand, strikes the woman. He shouts furiously as the soldiers wrestle her back aboard the truck.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: (deeply unsettled) Throughout my tour at Auschwitz, I never harmed anyone. I can say this absolutely and categorically. The truck begins to drive away. The woman throws herself over the side, clambers to her feet and runs blindly. Within seconds Mengele is upon her, striking her repeatedly with his cane, brutally and without mercy. At the first blow, Baumgarten turns his back.

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Everything I did was done with the utmost courtesy and professional concern. The woman falls and Mengele kicks her savagely. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: Some duties required great courage. When at last she lies still before him, Mengele turns and marches back to the platform. Soldiers throw the bloodied body onto the truck.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: This was medicine?

dialogues.speaker: BAUMGARTEN
dialogues.text: (with mounting fervor) Do you know what life was like at Auschwitz? Hell. A hell in which children and the old and weak suffered unspeakably -- with no hope for survival. A hell from which I offered the only escape. (then) Don't be naive, Peter. Medicine will never conquer every disease. And there will always come times when caring physicians must kill. (finally, barely a whisper ) This is the defense of Josef Mengele.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter looks at the old man as if at Satan himself.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Behold the Angel of Death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An austere, windowless accommodation of cold stone. Toilet, bed, chair and writing table. Separated by a wall of bars, Peter and Mengele sit facing away from one another. Peter's head is down, his eyes fixed on the Poor . Mengele appears exhausted. After a lengthy silence:

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: It's terrifying, Peter, these morons strutting around with shaved heads and baseball bats, playing dress-up like overgrown children. Denying anyone died at Auschwitz. Who do they think is going to believe that? Imbeciles. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (and) So easy to manipulate. But impossible to control. Mengele stands and steps to the bars.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: The size of your family -- it puts you in an extremely dangerous position. As a father, a son, a husband -- I sympathize. Peter never speaks.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: You can put a police guard on every dear one of them and then by some tragic mix-up at the pharmacy your father receives the wrong medication for his cardiac arythmia. Simple as that. Now Peter, full of thundering contempt, stands and faces Mengele, only the bars between them.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No member of my family must ever be threatened again. Agreed? Mengele smiles with his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: I think, Peter, you are being dragged kicking and screaming exactly where you've always wanted to go. HOLD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter hurries from a taxi into the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flight is about to board. Cory looks like she's just been told the most tasteless joke of her life.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Peter, be serious. She chokes out a strangled, disbelieving laugh. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: You agreed to defend Josef Mengele?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Not to defend him. To help him tell the absolute truth. Cory doesn't know what to say. This is too outrageous to comprehend.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for the punch line.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: There is no punch line. This is something I need to do.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: No. NO. What you need to do is get on this plane with me and go home. Peter wants nothing more than to do exactly that, but all he can say is:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Of course you can. Peter, you had one foot on the plane this afternoon. What happened? Peter turns away. Agonizing. Turns back.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Do you remember that story when I was nine or ten and I went sledding and crashed into my friend Erik's tree?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
