dialogues.text: Oh, Peter. Not this. Not now.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And Erik's sweet old uncle carried me inside and held me on his lap until my parents came? And sang Christmas carols in that awful voice, "Silent night, holy night," and I told my mother I thought he was the kindest, most wonderful man I'd ever met? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Peter -- I remember.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Do you remember what she told me?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: That during the war he'd been an officer at Treblinka.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: She told me that that kind, wonderful man was a killer. (beat ) She told me that my home town was full of killers. And that the cruelest and most monstrous of them all was a doctor. He was a doctor. How does a thing like that happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cory studies him. No sale.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Peter, what happened here this afternoon? He doesn't answer. Cory's flight is called. A line of passengers forms.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: This doesn't make sense. You're risking your practice. Risking your reputation. Risking us. What aren't you telling me? Peter is silent. Cory's fury boils over.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Peter, these people beat you and drugged you and shipped you halfway around the world -- and you could have died. And now you want to go back for more?! (stands) You'd better figure out what you're doing before you destroy everything that matters to you. She heads for the line of passengers.

dialogues.speaker: ON CORY
dialogues.text: In line with angry tears. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Peter watches her for a long moment before crossing to her. When at length he speaks, it is with a new and far more vulnerable tone.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Last summer, when your editor tried to kill herself -- Do you remember what you told me then, about needing to understand why?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I remember that I talked to her. I wrote about it. And I got past it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: But what if -- what if that same summer both your sisters had walked out on their families and checked themselves into psychiatric hospitals? And then you got a call that your mother had slit her wrists?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (appalled) Peter --

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you start to wonder? ground zero) If it could happen to you? She_ catches the brokenness in his voice and turns to really look at him. This is no idle curiosity at work but something far more visceral, issuing from deep within.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: What are you saying? You're afraid you're going to turn into someone like Josef Mengele? He can't answer, but what she sees in his wide eyes softens her.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: But don't you know how crazy that is? Nothing's like that is ever going to happen to you.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How do you know? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (hand to his cheek) Because you are a good man.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Am 1?

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: The very best.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Have you ever thought how many thousands of Germans it took to gas six million Jews? Don't you think any of those people started out like us? How do good people go bad, Cory? I've thought about it since the day I met that kind old killer... but never... ever... have I found an answer. (again) How do people go bad? Peter's soul laid bare before her, Cory looks at him with deep compassion.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Maybe Josef Mengele can tell me. And maybe then I can get past it. For the first time, Cory sees the inevitability of it all. She makes a huge and unwelcome decision, equal parts outrage and devotion. She steps out of line. Steps to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Damn you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE RINGS unanswered. Peter enters and hurries to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Rohm here... Yes, Horst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's grim.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: How serious are you about taking this case to trial? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why -- what's happening?

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: After you left him tonight, the old man collapsed in his cell. They think it's a stroke. Behind Voigt, medical personnel attend a prone patient. Federal police nearby.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (disbelief ) I was just with him -- How bad is he?

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Bad. On top of the stroke it looks like he's full of tumors.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Cancer?

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Everywhere but his eyeballs. He had to have known for months.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Is_ he... Is he conscious? Can he talk? Voigt looks across the ICU to Mengele, run through with probes and tubes, lying very still.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Right now, he can't do much of anything. He's drooling a little. I'm calling because the presiding judge was just here. We go to trial Monday morning.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Monday?! Three days?! Impossible.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: We have no choice. If we don't start Monday, we may not start at all. Cory has entered behind Peter. He looks to her with unbearable heaviness. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Rohm? Are you there?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (finally) I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: IN CLOUDS
dialogues.text: White wisps in the morning blue. A TELEPHONE is DIALED.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm trying to locate a Dr. Karl Gross. Is he at this number? CAMERA DESCENDS, taking in the top of a stately old building.

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dr. Heinrich Knaupt. I was told you might know his whereabouts.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, no, that's Beckmann. Dr. Julius Beckmann. B-E-C - KK... CAMERA CONTINUES its GLIDE DOWN the side of the grand structure.

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We're interested in talking to your grandfather.... I'm very sorry, I didn't know. STREET NOISE SURGES as CAMERA REACHES ground level, REVEALING a scene crawling with hawkers, gawkers, protesters, press and police. SUPERIMPOSE:

dialogues.speaker: CRIMINAL JUSTICE BUILDING, BERLIN
dialogues.text: CAMERA PUSHES FORWARD, PAST protestors holding signs that declare "NEVER AGAIN," BETWEEN television news crews, THROUGH a knot of tattooed thugs in leather jackets.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How's the patient? (frustrated beat) Call me if there's any change. CAMERA MOVES INTO the noisy lobby of the courthouse where officers perform body searches on everyone who enters.  62.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: The gallery is packed. Cory sits near the back, ill-at- ease. Behind her sits Mueller. A contingent of armed federal police sweeps in, followed by a medical team tending a gurney on which lies Mengele, plugged into a battery of portable monitors, eyes open but vacant, staring down and to the left. They whisk Mengele into a glass enclosure, a compact, bulletproof intensive care unit. Looking like he hasn't slept in days, Peter turns to Hillmann.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We have nothing, Felix. The trial's beginning and we have nothing. He shoves a sheet of legal paper toward Hillmann.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Check out these names.

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: Is it any use? Every doctor who ever studied or worked with him has died or disappeared. We've got to try something else.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The defendant's in a coma. Unless he wakes up... there is nothing else. Peter stuffs the list into Hillmann's hand.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Go. Hillmann moves off. Five solemn JUDGES sweep in and take seats behind the bench. There is no jury.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: On the record in the matter of Germany vs. Mengele, let the record show the defendant is present... Herr Rohm present for the defense... Herr Voigt for Germany. Voigt sits with a team of assistants.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Herr Voigt, you may proceed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Voigt rises with assurance, his manner straightforward and untheatrical.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Your Honors, Germany will show that the defendant, Josef Mengele, stood at the railroad sidings of Auschwitz and knowingly selected thousands upon thousands of individuals for death by gassing. (beat) That he performed fiendish experiments unparalleled in cruelty. After each charge Voigt pauses, allowing its full weight to register. A damning cadence.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: That he trafficked in the corpses of his victims, dispensing body parts like Christmas gifts. All attention in the courtroom is focused on the glass enclosure.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: That he stood on the abdomens of pregnant women causing their fetuses to be expelled. Cory recoils. Peter closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Germany will show that nobody made the defendant do these things. He did them because he wanted to, with the enthusiasm of a man who loved his work. Voigt's hand comes to rest atop an unmarked cardboard box on his table.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Half a century has passed since the defendant committed his crimes, and most witnesses have died. We're left with their sworn testimony -- (pulls a yellowed file from the box) -- affidavits describing in horrifying detail the crimes they suffered. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Voigt stuffs the file back in the box and carries it to the glass enclosure to gaze in at the accused.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Because of the extraordinary circumstances surrounding this trial, Germany has agreed to call only a limited number of witnesses. However, to do justice to the multitude of witnesses and victims we're unable to hear -- Voigt strides across the courtroom, CAMERA SWEEPING WITH him to reveal a mountain of boxes stacked to the ceiling, a staggering sight. Voigt adds his box to the mound.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: -- Germany submits their testimony for the record. Voigt takes his seat. The Presiding Judge looks to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: For the defense? Peter looks at the motionless defendant, the tantalizing stare, the head titled down and to the left as if he might simply be lost in thought. Peter turns back. Impotent.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Nothing at this time.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: Germany may call its first witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hillmann's bent over a telephone, papers and phone books spread across the bed.

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: (into phone) You have no idea where he went after he retired? He never phoned, never wrote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Frenchwoman in her sixties. Voigt stands before her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: (the memory vivid) We'd been on the train six days when the doors finally opened and everyone began jumping out. Soldiers shouted at us and pushed us into line. Up ahead, an officer was separating us into two groups. When we got close enough to see this officer, I was surprised that he was a handsome young man with a kind face. I'd been frightened by the soldiers but this face reassured me... Peter looks up, stirred by something in this testimony.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: He was whistling... and he pointed my sister and her baby to one side and me to the other. I spoke up and said she's my sister and couldn't we stay together. He said my sister was going toa special family camp, but we'd see one another later... I waved goodbye to Elisse, and the officer started whistling again...

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Did you in fact ever see your sister or niece after that?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: Of course not. There's no record they ever came to Auschwitz...

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Do you know the officer's name?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: (flat) Mengele.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: No further questions. Voigt returns to his seat.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Herr Rohm? Peter gazes at the inert defendant. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Makes an excruciating decision. He approaches the witness, respectful... but curious.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You said the soldiers were cruel.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: They had whips and were beating people to make them move faster, beating even the children.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did you see Dr. Mengele beat anyone?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did you hear him encourage the soldiers who were doing the beating?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: During your encounter with Dr. Mengele at the train ramp, did he strike you as a madman or a lunatic?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: (a_beat) Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: He stood out, you said, as a kind man. She thinks about that. Reluctant.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: He seemed to care about us... Peter's eyes find Cory in the gallery. This work turns his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the phone, aggravated beyond words. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: He's your husband. You want me to believe you don't know how to contact him?! Do you understand that this is a criminal proceeding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventies,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a wisp of a man. Voigt's before him.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN MAN
dialogues.text: Mengele woke me at about two AM and ordered me to set up lights and a phonograph. I'd barely finished when SS men brought hundreds of female prisoners out under the lights. It was a cold night, some snow on the ground, but all the women were naked. Mengele gave me a record album and told me to play it as loud as I could.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: What happened when the music started?

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN MAN
dialogues.text: He made the women dance... and then he walked among them, pointing out the most pathetic ones. Those he pointed out were taken to die. Peter with the same witness.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You said that when Dr. Mengele examined the women, he pointed out 'the most pathetic ones.' Do you mean he was looking for clumsy dancers?

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN MAN
dialogues.text: I mean he was looking for the weak ones, the sick ones, the ones who couldn't keep moving. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The weak ones and the sick ones. So his selections were based entirely on the women's physical condition... on medical criteria?

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN MAN
dialogues.text: More or less. Peter is unable to mask his own revulsion at his hideous task.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE GLASS ENCLOSURE
dialogues.text: Court in recess. Mengele lies propped in the bed, unchanged. Opposite him stands Peter, darkly watching the old man breathe. Peter squats, gets into Mengele's line of sight, gazes intensely into his eyes, watching, wondering.

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Peter -- Hillmann, energized, rushes toward him. Peter meets him outside the enclosure.

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: I think we've got a live one -- (hands him a scrap of paper) It was left at the hotel desk.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (reading) "Midnight tonight. Ravenstrasse 122. Stand before the lion' -- signed 'Beckmann.' (mystified) Beckmann -- the professor?

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: He's on your list. Mengele sent him shipments of ‘biological material' from Auschwitz -- club feet, skeletons of hunchbacks. Electrified, Peter gathers his papers. From the back of the courtroom, Mueller watches.  69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ancient section of the city. Old shops stretch along one side of the street; a vast cathedral rises on the other. The headlights of a lone car sweep around a distant corner.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Stand before the lion.' (then) What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Five to midnight.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Do you see 122? The car pulls alongside the church. A flashlight searches and comes to rest on three digits above the cathedral entrance: 122.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A graveyard encircles the church. Peter and Hillmann move to an iron gate.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey, Felix -- see any lions?

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: No lions.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Keep your eyes open. He pushes open the gate. Two steps in, he's stopped by a FERAL HISSING. Hillmann leaps back as Peter probes wildly with the flashlight, catching the red glint of feline eyes before settling on a bloated tomcat. The CAT MOANS with an almost human cry, then waddles languidly out the gate. Sharing an edgy chuckle, they traverse the graveyard to the church entrance. Peter tries the door. It's locked. He shines his light through a window, sees nothing. Easing along the side of the church, they round a corner and a lighted sculpture comes into view, stopping them in their tracks: a placid lamb snuggled against a huge stone lion.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: ‘And the lion shall lie down with the lamb...' (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They hurry through the tombstones to the base of the statue. Peter shines his light around.

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: (calls) Dr. Beckmann? Hello? Dr. Beckmann? (checks watch) Midnight straight up. Could we have missed him? Peter's light has come to rest on a grave marker directly before the statue.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (darkly) We didn't miss him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAVE MARKER
dialogues.text: "JULIUS BECKMANN, Beloved Husband, Father, Physician,

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Hillmann gives Peter a sick, betrayed look.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Let's get some sleep. They turn to go. DISEMBODIED LAUGHTER RINGS OUT. In the shadow of the stone lion, something moves. Peter and Hillmann take an involuntary step backward as a tall, skeletal wraith emerges.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Mueller. Of course. The old attorney takes up a position directly behind Beckmann's gravestone.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: (mocking) "Dr. Beckmann?... Dr. Beckmann?!" (smiles) Regrettably, Dr. Beckmann is... indisposed. Peter is furious.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Do you know how much of my time you just wasted? We're a week into the trial and I have nothing. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Nothing but a big phone bill. Oh yes, I've heard all about your fruitless search for witnesses. You call them, they call me -- (beat ) It's too bad you can't chat with Beckmann. He was so fond of our friend. (beat) Did you know he obtained money from the German Research Council to build the doctor a laboratory at Auschwitz?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I know something about what he got for his money -- the little packages that came in the mail...

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: And what should he have done, thrown priceless scientific material in the garbage? For him, it was an opportunity to understand human disease. Perhaps even to ease suffering.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (acidly) Will he testify to that in court? Wake up, Mueller. You're an attorney. I need someone I can put on the stand.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Maybe you should take your client's advice and recruit some nice Dutch doctors.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What the hell can Dutch doctors tell us? They resisted the Nazi medicine -- many of them to the death.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: No, Peter. Not then. Now. Then Mueller waves it off, as if he doesn't mean to be taken seriously. He examines the grave marker. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Did you know that even before the war, good Dr. Beckmann lobbied Hitler for permission to extend mercy to a number of children under his care?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (to Hillmann; he's heard enough) Let's get out of here. Peter and Hillmann start across the churchyard. Mueller allows them a few steps before dropping his bombshell.

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Of course this was before the university. While he was still director at Wuerzbach. The information has its desired effect: Peter turns back as if shot. And can't stop himself from asking:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Beckmann was at Wuerzbach?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: Didn't you know?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (incredulous) The Wuerzbach Children's Clinic?

dialogues.speaker: MUELLER
dialogues.text: (offhand) He had an excellent staff. Very supportive. Very forward- thinking. (then) I thought you would have known... you know, because of your mother. Peter's heart has stopped. Mueller smiles his smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cory's asleep. Peter lies beside her, unable to still his troubled thoughts. He picks up the bedside phone then just as quickly replaces it. Agonized, he stares at the phone before lifting the receiver and dialing a number he knows by heart. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hello -- it's me... I'm sorry to call so -- No, everything's fine. We're both -- Wakened by his call, Cory rolls over.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I was just... I couldn't sleep and -- He falls into silence. Cory watches him until:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mama. I shouldn't have called. (finally) I just needed to hear your voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again Cory sits in the back of the gallery. On the stand is RACHEL, a woman in her sixties, well-dressed, composed. She has no right arm.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: All his twins they kept ina place we called the Zoo. Him we called... (a_look toward Mengele) Him we called Uncle Pepi. Mengele's arms lie neatly at his sides. His gaze remains fixed as before, down and to the left.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: He made sure we got enough to eat. Soft beds. Clothes. Ribbons for our hair. And chocolate. Always there was chocolate when Uncle Pepi visited his children. We were eleven, my sister Sarah and I, and we thought... we thought he was so handsome... (trails off as she glances again toward the enclosure) One day he came for Sarah and me. He made it a game. Follow the leader. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mengele's No change. 74.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He made us laugh... We followed to the hospital where they measured us, it was so strange, our noses and ears and around our heads. And they said... They said take off your dresses so Uncle Pepi can look at you. (shivers) He looked... at everything. Comparing every possible detail, looking, looking, looking. nurse glances at a monitor, makes a notation.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: When he finished looking, he strapped us to examination tables and made little marks with his pen, one on my arm and one on Sarah's. He said be brave, it's going to hurt a little, and he cut with a knife along the marks. Then he smeared something in the cuts. We didn't cry and he said it made him happy that we were so brave. (her composure falters) That we were such good girls. She blinks at Voigt, who waits patiently. The courtroom is silent.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I woke up that night back in the Zoo, soaked in sweat. My arm was burning, all red and swollen around the cut. Sarah's was worse. We begged to see Uncle Pepi, to get medicine, but they said he was busy. We waited for three days before he sent for us. Three days. Forever. Sarah's fingers were black, and when he saw that my fingers hadn't turned, he was fascinated. We begged him, please help us, do something, we had so much pain. He told us that we mustn't cry. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (and so she doesn't) Three days later the camp was liberated and I never saw him again. Until today. (pause) Sarah died. A Russian doctor took my arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A POLISH WOMAN, 75, testifies. In the glass enclosure, the nurse is not yet aware of a new sound -- her patient's odd WHEEZING.

dialogues.speaker: POLISH WOMAN
dialogues.text: (vehemently) He was an animal. I came to Auschwitz with two sets of twins, two sons and two daughters, and he wanted to know how I got so many twins. A STRANGLED COUGH from Mengele finally turns the nurse's head. He's moved, arms askew, an IV line torn free.

dialogues.speaker: POLISH WOMAN
dialogues.text: "At what age did you first make love?' 'How many lovers did you have beside your husband?'  'How often are you with a lover?' (stands to address Mengele directly) I have a question for you, Butcher! If you love twins so much, why did you kill mine?! But her rage turns to horror when the nurse moves aside to reveal that Mengele's head has turned so that he now looks straight back at his accuser. He coughs.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE GLASS ENCLOSURE
dialogues.text: Nurse and doctor work on Mengele who labors for each breath. His eyes fall on Peter. The old man tries to speak. No words come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter gazes darkly across the street at a two-story brick building distinguished by the words above the entrance: "THE WUERZBACH CLINIC FOR CHILDREN'S MEDICINE." He teeters between an urge to flee and an inescapable need to know.  76.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON THE FACE OF A CLOWN
dialogues.text: Bulbous nose, red lips, a single blue tear. LAUGHTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children surround the clown, many in wheelchairs, others leaning on walkers or crutches. One slouches in her seat, head hanging to the side, drooling into her lap. Another rocks back and forth, moaning grotesquely. The clown sifts through a boy's hair and produces a tiny white mouse. The boy's eyes grow huge. Gasps of delight. A door opens and Peter steps in. A hulking teen wearing knee pads and a protective helmet lurches toward Peter with a huge welcoming grin. Peter flinches reflexively. A staff member redirects the patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter strides past treatment rooms, patient rooms, an X- ray lab, catching sight everywhere of disabled young patients. He reaches a stairway and ascends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SECRETARY's a brusque, efficient woman of about 60. She's on the phone when Peter enters.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: You'll have to wait until Thursday. The director will be out of the office tomorrow. She hangs up and looks to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Yes, how can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: My name's Peter Rohm. I called. A half beat, then the Secretary dials a two-digit code and turns away from Peter, speaking with hushed intensity. The door to the inner office opens and DOCTOR FRANK emerges, an energetic, baby-faced man in his thirties.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Doctor Frank? I'm Peter Rohm --

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. And as I told you on the phone, I don't have time to deal with you now. Frank continues past Peter and out of the office.  77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter overtakes the fast-moving Frank on the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Doctor, if you could give me even a few minutes -- Frank reaches steps into the X-ray lab. Peter waits impatiently as Frank huddles with another doctor. When the consultation concludes Frank exits the lab and continues down the corridor, Peter at his side.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'd like to look at your records for the years Julius Beckmann was here.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: Where's your court order?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Am I going to need one? Frank enters a patient room, peruses a chart, makes a notation, then exits and continues his forced march.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: We're very busy today. Come back tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Tomorrow? Fine. And when I come back and you're not here -- I'll just start interviewing your employees.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: You stay away from my employees.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why? What are you hiding? What happened here?! Frank turns on Peter.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: Nothing happened here! This clinic was founded as a haven for children no one else wanted. We don't kill our patients -- and we never have. Ever. So don't drag us into your defense of that butcher. The depth of Frank's conviction gives Peter pause. He softens slightly. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don't intend to drag you into anything, Doctor. My interest here isn't professional. It's personal. Frank's eyebrows go up. A moment as each man evaluates the other A moment. anew.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How much do you really know about what was done here during the war? Have you been through the records?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: (just a tad off the point) Nothing in those records bears on your case.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Meaning you haven't been through them?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: (exasperated) I've only been here eight weeks. I'm a pediatric surgeon, not a historian.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Then you don't really know anything, do you.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: After you called, I talked to my secretary. She's been here forever. If there'd been killing, she would know. (and) She's absolutely reliable.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Then you wouldn't object if I talked to her myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE IS RINGING. After three or four rings, the door opens and Frank leads Peter in. He looks around. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: Karin? But the Secretary is nowhere to be found. Frank looks inside his inner office. Emerges. Giving Peter an odd look. This isn't right. The PHONE continues to RING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little-used access to the clinic's basement. Peter and Frank descend to a locked door. Frank awkwardly inserts a key. The old lock resists and he must struggle before it turns and the door swings open. He switches on a light, revealing row upon row of ancient medical files bathed in dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cory's on the phone when Peter blasts in, face grim.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (to phone) -- Then let's move that paragraph up... No it doesn't, not if you cut the reference to Munich. Peter throws things into a suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (covers mouthpiece) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I have to catch a train.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (into phone) I'll call you back. (quickly hangs up) What do you mean -- where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Home. He snaps his suitcase and looks at her, sick with unwelcome knowledge. A DIESEL GROWL BUILDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ROAR CRESCENDOS. Out of the darkness THUNDERS a DIESEL LOCOMOTIVE trailing a string of passenger cars.  80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearly everyone is asleep. Peter sits awake, staring out as the lights of the countryside flash past. Cory sits beside him, also awake, silent and dismayed.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: A fist pounds. The door opens to reveal a sleepy Max.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Peter --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter stands on his parents' front porch with Cory.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: What's wrong? Without a word, Peter enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter takes the stairs two at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter steps into the room. He's trembling.

dialogues.speaker: HILDE
dialogues.text: Peter! Are you all right? Max and Cory arrive in time to hear:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I've been at Wuerzbach, Mama. Going through old records. Hilde's mouth opens. No sound comes out.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: In the last half of 1939 -- your first year there -- over 50 children died of 'an adverse reaction to medication.' (then) What happened, Mama?... Tell me you didn't know. But there's no fight in her eyes, no denial. Only great sadness. And shame. Peter deflates like a ruptured balloon, sinking back against the door frame.  81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Hilde face one another across the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: HILDE
dialogues.text: I was 21 years old when I started at Wuerzbach, straight out of nursing school. In those days the place was full of babies with the most heart-breaking deformities. I'd change their diapers and give them bottles, but at the end of my shift I'd go home and cry because I wanted to do so much more. We all did. (beat ) Some of the parents had heard rumors of children at other hospitals, severely impaired children, receiving certain medication... certain doses of medication... And they asked us why we couldn't do the same for their children... They were very insistent. And it seemed... at the time it seemed... so wise and... so good. Peter sags beneath the weight of his mother's words. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How were they killed?

dialogues.speaker: HILDE
dialogues.text: A sedative was added to the child's water, and after two or three days, after he'd had enough, he just fell asleep... Peter looks directly at his mother and asks the most horrible question.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What was your role, Mama?

dialogues.speaker: HILDE
dialogues.text: My role...? I was never asked to administer the sedative, if that's what you mean. (a_ beat; naked) But I would have. Peter's eyes are locked on Hilde. A tear appears. Then he does something unexpected. He moves to his mother, slides his arms around her and holds on.  82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Cory exit the Volvo and walk silently to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light is switched on. Peter and Cory stand inside the front door. Laundry is piled on the couch. Dirty dishes and a jug of soured milk are on the table.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I left in such a hurry. She begins cleaning up. Peter hasn't moved. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: While my mother was talking, something came back to me. Something I'd forgotten until now. (this haunts him) It was after she told me about Erik's uncle and Treblinka. She said, "You must be careful, Peter. It can happen to anyone." (beat ) Those were her words. Cory watches him as he stands thinking about that for a long, long moment. He steps abruptly to a closet, pulls out a cardboard box and heads upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sweeps a stack of files from his desk into the box. He steps to the file cabinet and jerks open the second drawer, "G-M." It sticks. He yanks furiously, pulling it completely out of the cabinet. It crashes to the floor. Peter picks up files of yellowed pages and dumps them in the box. He digs in the closet for the SS uniform. This also goes in the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter throws open the back door and crosses the yard to a trash bin. He dumps the box. The SS uniform spills onto the ground. Peter stands over it, head bent low, shoulders heaving. Cory watches from the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter enters and picks through the debris. Cory appears in the doorway. He glances up, made uncomfortable by her presence, then returns to his work but is unable to escape the sensation of her eyes upon him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What? Cory shakes her head. Nothing. He steps to his desk and discards computer disks. She keeps watching.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It's over. You should be thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (simply) No.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You told me to stay off this case. You warned me. She just keeps watching until he can take it no longer and stops his work, still looking away from her.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Just say it. What? Cory waits. At last, her tone unaccusing:

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Explain to me what's going to happen when court resumes and you're not there.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Felix will just have to handle it.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Six weeks out of law school -- I didn't know he was ready for a case like this.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (voice near breaking) Well neither am I. If Peter were to look at Cory, he'd see tears in her eyes. He doesn't. Instead, he scoops up the papers and diskettes and starts out of the room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: So you'll leave it like this -- your mother and Josef Mengele lumped together under the heading pogod people of Gunzburg gone ad." Peter stops in the doorway. Turns back. And for the first time sees Cory's tears.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: That night at the airport, when you told me you were taking this case -- I had to make a decision. Because I knew that when you go after the truth, you go wherever it leads, no matter what it costs, all the way to the end. (then) I hate this, Peter. I hate that you took this case. But I love you. So I chose to come along. Cory crosses to stand directly before her husband.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Don't leave us halfway there. He draws a long, uneven breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An anxiety-ridden Hillmann charges down a dim and little-trafficked passageway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great commotion as guards noisily unlock the cell door and slide it open. In his bed at the center of the cell, Josef Mengele, remarkably alert and exceedingly agitated, strains to see who's arrived. His voice is weak and rasping but he can once again speak.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Is he here? His left arm lies limp at his side, the left side of his face is unresponsive, and every word comes with difficulty. Hillmann steps into his field of view.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: I don't want you. I want Peter. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... we can't seem to locate him.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Can't locate -- Mengele thinks half a beat.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Get me the prosecutor.

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: I beg your --

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Voigt. Get him, dammit! I want to talk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hush in the packed courtroom as Mengele is wheeled into the enclosure. His bed is positioned and a microphone is swung into position. Hillmann sits alone at the defense table, his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: Back on the record in the matter of Germany vs. Mengele. Herr Voigt present for Germany, Herr Hillmann for the defense. (beat ) Does the defendant understand that if he testifies this morning, it will be asa prosecution witness, against the advice and over the objections of counsel?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: I do. Mengele's VOICE, though frail, is AMPLIFIED so that it fills the room. His WHEEZING, too, is eerily MAGNIFIED.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: Has the defendant come to this decision voluntarily, without threat or coercion?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: I have. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: Your Honor, please --

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: (overriding) Then, in view of the defendant's precarious health and the overriding value of his testimony, the court is going to overrule defense objections.

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: (standing) Your Honor --

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: Herr Hillmann, the court has noted your strenuous objections. (beat ) Germany may proceed. Hillmann sinks helplessly into his seat as Voigt rises and approaches the enclosure. Mengele gazes back with death-defying determination. He coughs

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Doctor Mengele. During the period May 1943 to January 1945, did you in fact serve as a physician at the Auschwitz concentration camp?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Is it true that you came to Auschwitz as a volunteer?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: No one ordered you. You volunteered.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Yes. painfully. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: While at Auschwitz, were you at times responsible for certifying death at mass gassings?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Yes. Hillmann glances toward the closed door at the rear of the courtroom. No sign of Peter.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Is it true that you were often present when inmates were unloaded from arriving trains?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Who was responsible on those occasions for determining the immediate destination of each of those new arrivals?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: I was. Voigt's astonished by how easy this is.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Germany has given evidence that you were present on well over forty occasions. Would you dispute that number? There's a tiny glimmer of fire in the dull eyes. An infinitesimal show of strength.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: It was a big job.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Did you expose prisoners to X- rays in so-called experiments aimed at sterilizing them?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Again Hillmann looks for Peter. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day is wearing on. Mengele is tiring.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Did you, in order to rida barracks of typhus, once send all 600 residents of that barracks to be gassed?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Did you participate -- (breaks off) No. I'm going to read this, I want to get it exactly right. He picks up a legal pad and pages forward, unable to hold in check his indignation.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: "Dump trucks carrying 300 children under the age of five were driven to the edge of a burning pit. The children were thrown screaming into the fire. Soldiers circled the pit, pushing any child who crawled out back into the flames." He looks at Mengele with burning eyes.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Did you give orders at such an action? A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: (forcefully) Did you give orders at such an action?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: (finally) Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Then damn you, Doctor. God damn you. He turns away.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: No more questions. Mengele goes slack with exhaustion.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: Is the defense prepared to question the witness at this time?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: We are, Your Honor. Peter, standing just inside the door at the back of the courtroom, steps away from Cory and strides rapidly forward, taking the court by surprise. He works without notes, his tone conversational, almost casual.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Doctor, you agree that in your fight against typhus you sent hundreds of women to be gassed. Mengele seems revived by Peter's return.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Were you honestly trying to stop the epidemic -- or just looking for an excuse to kill Jews?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: (moral outrage) I am a doctor. I regarded these women as my patients.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And the fact is that before your arrival at Auschwitz, no one had been able to stop the epidemics which repeatedly ravaged the camp, is that correct?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: That is correct. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: But with your admittedly harsh measures, you brought the epidemics under control.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Doctor, have you ever had typhus?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: I contracted it at Auschwitz. Mengele is rising to the battle, with each answer his voice growing incrementally stronger. Voigt can

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Earlier that same year, also serving at Auschwitz, you contracted malaria.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And before Auschwitz, you were decorated for braving enemy fire on the Russian front to pull wounded soldiers from a burning tank.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Again and again you put your life at risk to save others. take no more of this.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Objection. Is counsel questioning the witness or nominating him for a Nobel Prize? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I'm simply introducing the facts of the doctor's life. I didn't expect to make such an impression on the prosecutor.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: Overruled. Proceed. Peter turns back to Mengele, but when he speaks again, his tone is anything but casual. He's come to the very heart of the matter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Doctor Mengele, on the battlefield you risked your life to save wounded soldiers. Then again at Auschwitz you risked your life to save dying Jews. (beat ) How is it possible that you also gave orders to throw children into a burning pit? It's a question that gives even Josef Mengele pause. For the first time, he doesn't know his next line.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You've described Auschwitz as hell.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You can't mean for yourself. You were privileged, you had rank and respect, you lacked nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: I mean hell.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Even for yourself, then.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: For everyone. It was indescribable. The camp was full, we had no food, but the trains never stopped coming. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And you were the man responsible for meeting those trains.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: This was my task.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You were responsible for deciding who from those trains lived and who died.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: They were all dead. When they stepped off the train. Dead already. This was not my decision. (and) I saved as many as I could.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You saved the twins.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Yes, twins who now testify against me. Don't they know they owe me their lives?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why didn't you save them all? The idea is so foreign that Mengele can't immediately grasp it.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Save them all? Everyone?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: I would have destroyed the camp! Don't you understand? There were too many. Peter waits.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Should I have condemned the old grandmothers to that hell of Slave labor and disease? (turns to attendant) Raise me up a little. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The attendant elevates the back of Mengele's bed.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Should I have damned the little ones to a slow death by starvation? Granting them a quick end was a great kindness.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A quick end in a burning pit.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: (emphatically) We had_no choice. (then) Have you ever seen a child gassed? They don't die well. We were forced to find other means. (to attendant) Water. The attendant pours water from a pitcher. Mengele drinks, invigorated.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The experiments, Doctor. My God, the experiments. You've admitted conducting painful medical investigations on children without anesthetic --

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Can't you understand? They were dead. I found them on their way to the crematorium. I experimented. Yes I experimented! I drew from their deaths meaning -- scientific knowledge that might benefit others more fortunate. (and) Anything less would have been criminal.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You inflicted a great deal of suffering. You induced raging infections and left them untreated. (again) You used no anesthetic. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: I_had no anesthetic. (with astonishing vigor) A surgeon sees gangrene, he has no anesthetic, but he amputates the limb. Do you call witnesses against the doctor to tell how he hacked with his saw, how blood spattered his smock, how the patient screamed? Of course not. Do you know what you do? (voice booming) You say, "Thank God. Thank God for the doctor."

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: His head has risen off his pillow and he's fixed the Judges with a burning gaze. Then he looks to Peter and his features soften into a look that approximates affection. A ghastly sight.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: recoils from the look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter lies back. His eyes remain wide open, tormented. Cory joins him. Without a word, he turns off the light.

dialogues.speaker: DREAM SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: A LATCH IS THROWN and a HEAVY CATTLE-CAR DOOR RUMBLES aside, unveiling a blazing square of light. SOLDIERS appear, bathed in light.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIERS
dialogues.text: Raus! Raus! Bodies tumble from the car into the light.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Floodlights of unearthly brilliance cast harsh shadows. Soldiers strip the arrivals of every possession and herd them into line. Forced INTO this hapless procession, CAMERA LOOKS AHEAD. Rising above those in line, a handsome young SS officer stands on a platform, his eyes locked on the head of the line, his right hand extended over them, flicking right, left, right, left, left, left. CAMERA SLOWLY NEARS the officer, the prisoners ahead streaming into darkness, until the officer's eyes fall directly ON CAMERA. He stops. His face lights up with wonder. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MENGELE
dialogues.text: Peter. He hurries down the platform steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the head of the endless procession of the damned, Peter is taken into Mengele's embrace.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MENGELE
dialogues.text: Peter, I'm so grateful you've come. CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter snaps on the light, breathing hard, drenched in sweat. He looks hard at himself in the mirror. A long, long look full of doubt and loathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Court in session. Mengele, in the glass enclosure, is again at the microphone as Voigt redirects.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: There's been a lot of talk in this room, and I want to make sure I'm still clear on the facts. You've testified that while at Auschwitz you participated in mass gassings. Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: That's correct.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Was that testimony the truth?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: My testimony was factual.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Your testimony was factual... And when you testified that you sent all 600 residents of a particular barracks to their deaths, were you telling the truth then? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: I acknowledged the facts -- which are not always the same as the truth, Herr Prosecutor.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Ah... then let's just stick to facts. You sent the 600 women to their deaths. Fact?

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Is it so hard to understand? Have you no one in your world whose life has lost meaning?

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: (overriding) Fact or fiction, Doctor? Answer the question.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Is no one today suffering hopelessly?

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Your Honor --

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: The witness is directed to answer the question. Unheeding, Mengele leans into the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Is there no one, no one unwanted? Something here strikes a chord in Cory.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: The witness will answer the question.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Medicine will always need doctors with the courage to kill.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: (furious) Cut him off.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: If you want the truth, read your newspaper. You'll see I'm telling you -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The microphone goes dead, silencing Mengele whose mouth continues to move inside the enclosure. Voigt's disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: No more questions. Cory scribbles furiously.

dialogues.speaker: NO. 700
dialogues.text: Cory's on a public phone.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Paul, hi, it's me. Didn't you once tell me you had a doctor friend in Amsterdam? (beat ) Can you put me in touch with her? (and) Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter enters alone.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Cory? No answer. Her things are gone. Peter finds a folded note on his pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cory clears customs. Signs in five languages welcome her to Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cory ducks into a taxi.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Rykstadt Main Hospital.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER TAXI, SOMEWHERE IN BERLIN
dialogues.text: An elderly woman climbs out and tugs her coat tightly around her. Hilde. Peter exits the cab behind her.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You don't need to do this.

dialogues.speaker: HILDE
dialogues.text: I've needed to do this for 50 years.  98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: reveals they stand on the steps of the Wuerzbach Clinic for Children's Medicine. Sharing a wordless look, they start for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Frank, the clinic director, passes, followed by Peter and Hilde. They walk purposefully. Hilde looks at the children. Remembering. Peter, too, studies the children. It's impossible to know what he's seeing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The narrow, dim, little-used access to the basement. Frank, Peter and Hilde descend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cory waits. A young woman with a vibrant smile appears.

dialogues.speaker: DR. VAN KONINGSVELD
dialogues.text: Cory Rohm? (extending her hand) I'm Dr. van Koningsveld. How can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, Hilde and Dr. Frank pore over old records. Frank finds something of interest in a file he's studying and lays it aside, atop a short stack of similar folders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The animated Dr. van Koningsveld leads Cory through the bustle of this gleamingly modern hospital. Cory holds a microcassette recorder.

dialogues.speaker: DR. VAN KONINGSVELD
dialogues.text: Economics is always an issue. Do you --

dialogues.speaker: ORDERLY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Excuse us. They step aside to make way for a passing gurney and Cory comes face to face with the patient, a woman in her nineties. Her head lolls toward Cory, her eyes and mouth gaping wide in an agonized, voiceless wail. The gurney turns a quick corner and she's gone. Van Koningsveld explains with sympathy:

dialogues.speaker: VAN KONINGSVELD
dialogues.text: Bone cancer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She begins again:

dialogues.speaker: VAN KONINGSVELD
dialogues.text: Anyway, economics is always a big issue. Do you have any idea how much we spend on patients in their last 30 days of life -- people who tragically are never going to get better? It's staggering. Cory's still looking back at the spot where the gurney disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, Hilde and Dr. Frank continue their search. Frank's stack has grown dramatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cory and Dr. van Koningsveld are joined by a RESIDENT who indicates a severely-afflicted adolescent.

dialogues.speaker: RESIDENT
dialogues.text: She's never had a coherent thought. She'll never speak an intelligible word. She's fed through a tube. Her parents visit the first and fifteenth of each month. The state pays the bill. So you can understand that people begin to ask if there isn't another way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilde leads Peter and Frank through the clinic. She moves as if in a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunlight and cheerful colors. Hilde enters, trailed by Peter and Frank. She stops just inside the room. After a moment, she moves with assurance toward a back corner.

dialogues.speaker: BACK CORNER
dialogues.text: Peter, Hilde and Frank watch as workmen peel the carpeting slowly back to expose bare concrete. Hilde flinches, as if she herself is being exposed. Peter bends and runs his hand over the concrete. Clearly visible in the floor: a distinct line of old bolt holes describing a perfect square the size of a small bedroom. Peter sits dead center in the square. Imagining.  100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lounge filled with elderly patients. Cory and van Koningsveld talk to a young INTERN.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: By the time you get to their age you've seen a few people die, and not always well, if you know what I mean. So they're afraid. Afraid of the pain, of course, but more than that, afraid it's going to be drawn out -- and if that happens, terrified of what it's going to do to the people they love. Fortunately, the legal situation in this country permits us to take an active medical role to ensure that doesn't happen.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: An active medical role, meaning...

dialogues.speaker: INTERN
dialogues.text: Humane methods have been developed. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl of seven or eight, her body frail and bent and propped in a pediatric wheelchair. With her one good arm she wheels herself in circles, finding in that act a blazing joy that explodes in her twisted, gaping smile. Close by and rapt, Peter watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open bed truck off-loads pipe beside this large, prosperous old firm. A taxi delivers Peter and he enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: Daylight is waning as Peter exits and heads for a waiting cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter steps to the front door of an especially handsome house. He knocks and waits. The door is opened by a friendly WOMAN in her 60s. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Woman 101.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Is this the home of Edvard Nielson?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Is he here?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: One moment. disappears into the house. A jovial, balding MAN in his 70s appears.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Edvard Nielson?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON, (MAN)
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: My name's Peter Rohm. I'm an attorney representing Josef Mengele in his current trial. Nielson's bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: May I come in?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: But... why would you want to talk to me?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Herr Nielson... During the winter of 1940, were you employed by the Durenburger Plumbing Works? And finally Nielson understands -- and slams the door in Peter's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A roomful of infants and small children at death's door, surrounded by high-tech medical machinery. A _heart- rending sight. A PHYSICIAN in his forties walks with Cory among the sick. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PHYSICIAN
dialogues.text: Please understand -- this is what I see every day. It's the only way you can really fathom what I'm telling you. (indicates a patient) Look there. Cory steps to the bedside of a tiny newborn, her eyes taped shut, breathing tube, NG tube, multiple IVs.

dialogues.speaker: PHYSICIAN
dialogues.text: You'll notice how quiet our children are. No crying. We must keep them so sedated. (then) Can you look at this child and tell me you see life? Not in the ordinary sense of the word, you can't. We're learning in these cases to do what's right for the patients. It's a medical service that benefits thousands in this country every year.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: (horrified irony) "Thank God for the doctor." (then) This medical service, is it provided with the patient's consent?

dialogues.speaker: PHYSICIAN
dialogues.text: (eyes on his patient) How can she possibly consent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cory enters and pulls off her shoes at the end of one of the longest days of her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sits on the edge of his bed watching television news coverage of the trial. Weary and alone.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: Full-blown riot. An army of anti-Nazi demonstrators hurls rocks and bottles at neo-Nazi zealots. Police drive both sides apart with dogs, truncheons and water cannons.  103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hillmann's rental sedan skirts the violence to deliver Peter, who is muscled by police to the courthouse door. He ignores the shouts of press and protestors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stark contrast of judicial silence. Seated upright in a wheelchair, only a single IV in evidence, Mengele is wheeled into the enclosure.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: Back on the record in Germany versus Mengele. (and) Defense may proceed. Peter rises.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The defense calls Dr. Karl Frank director of the Wuerzbach Clinic for Children's Medicine.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Objection. Does this witness possess firsthand knowledge of the defendant? Did the defendant ever work in his clinic?

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: Germany has had its turn, Herr Prosecutor. Overruled. Dr. Frank is ushered to the stand. Mengele watches with intense interest.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Dr. Frank, what sort of institution is the Wuerzbach Clinic?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: We're an in-patient medical facility caring for children with chronic disabilities.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: In addition to directing the clinic, you yourself are a pediatric surgeon, correct?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes I am. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And as such you're accustomed to reading patient files.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: Of course. Peter takes a stack of files from the defense table and sets them in front of the witness. Cory slips into the back of the courtroom, catching Peter's eye, and squeezes into a seat.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: These files represent 51 patients who died at your clinic during the last six months of 1939. Do you recognize the files?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: (flips open top file and glances inside) Yes I do.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You've studied them?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Does anything about them strike you as unusual from a medical standpoint?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Fifty-one patients, suffering a variety of ailments -- severe deformities, mongolism, microcephaly -- are listed as having died of the exact same cause.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What cause was that?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: According to the records -- (reads from top file) "An adverse reaction to medication." Hilde sits motionless. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Fifty-one deaths in six months from an adverse reaction to medication. That's unusual?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: It's beyond belief.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Meaning the records are inaccurate?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: Meaning the records are a lie.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Can you tell the court what you think did cause those deaths?

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Objection. Speculation.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: Sustained. A beat. Peter adopts another approach.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Besides cause of death, did the files contain anything else notable in common?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: Each file held an identical letter addressed to the parents. (reads) "We regret to inform you of the death of your child. This death should not be considered a tragedy. Under the circumstances, the death should be viewed as a merciful release."

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (repeats) ",,. Death should be viewed as a merciful release." Peter looks significantly toward the glass enclosure, then returns to his table and collects a much taller stack of files, which he deposits before Frank. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: These files represent patient deaths for the three months beginning January of 1940. Have you examined these files?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes I have.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And what did you find?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: They show a sharp increase in the rate of patient deaths over the previous period, from 51 deaths in six months up to 452 deaths in just three months.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So somewhere around the first of January 1940, a death rate you've described as already beyond belief jumped sharply.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did you note any other changes?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: Deaths during this period occurred among those much less severely ill, including patients with minor facial deformities, cleft palate, undesirable behaviors --

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Undesirable behaviors? Such as what?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: (a beat) Bed-wetters.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Bed-wetters? And they came to your clinic and died?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: According to these records. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Any change in the letters?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: Not one word.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: They still said these deaths were to be viewed as -- what did they say?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: A merciful release.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A merciful release. Mengele listens smugly.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Doctor, can you tell the court for a fact what happened at the beginning of January 1940 to account for this sudden increase in deaths?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR FRANK
dialogues.text: For a fact? No.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Thank you, Doctor. No more questions.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: Prosecution? Voigt makes a show of throwing up his hands in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: No questions.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: The witness is excused. Frank stands and exits.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: Herr Rohm?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Your Honor, the defense calls Edvard Nielson. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: An exceedingly reluctant Nielson is escorted to the stand.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Herr Nielson, what is your occupation?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: I'm a retired plumbing contractor.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And in January 1940?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: I was a plumber.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: Objection! A plumber? What does any of this have to do with the defendant's crimes? (then) Your Honor, Germany moves to bar further testimony in this matter as immaterial and requests a verdict on the evidence presented. Peter is caught off guard by Voigt's surprise motion.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (quickly) Your Honor, may we approach? The Presiding Judge nods and both Peter and Voigt move to the bench.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Surely the court won't deny the defendant his defense.

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: What defense is possible? He's confessed to every charge.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, Your Honor, no. The doctor has admitted no guilt. He's simply stipulated to the facts of his actions -- actions he contends were a logical extension of the medicine practiced at that time throughout Germany. The testimony of this witness will corroborate that view. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: VOIGT
dialogues.text: (outraged) What view?! That there's some connection between what took place in a medical clinic and the wholesale butchery of Auschwitz?! That's obscene!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Your Honor, if we can hear the witness, I believe the connection will become clear. The Presiding Judge considers at length.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: Let no one say this court denied any defendant a fair trial. Motion denied; we'll hear the witness. Voigt reacts in exasperation as he and Peter return to their places. No answer

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Herr Nielson, are you familiar with an institution known as the Wuerzbach Clinic for Children's Medicine? is forthcoming.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Herr Nielson?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: I'm familiar.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: In January 1940, were you sent to that institution to do some plumbing work?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Right after the New Year's holiday.

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: That's right. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It wasn't an ordinary plumbing job, was it? Tell the court what you remember about the project. Nielson stares at the floor. Peter crosses back to his table and a final sheaf of aged paper.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You do remember the project, don't you? Because we can introduce a number of documents to refresh your memory.

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: I remember. (pause) They were building a room --

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What sort of room?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: A little room. Sealed all the way around, top and bottom -- like a big shower, with one set of pipes going in, another set coming out.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So you, what, hooked up the pipes?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: Hooked up the pipes. Checked for leaks. They were very concerned about that. Didn't want any leaks.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: They who? Who was in charge?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: The doctors. I did exactly what the doctors told me.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did you know what you were building?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: I asked; no one seemed to know. Finally one of the doctors told me it was for an experimental new treatment. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: An experimental new treatment. Did you ever discover the nature of that treatment?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: Not the first time. But later, when they sent me back.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: They sent you back? Why?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: They wanted me to take it down.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Really. When was this?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: About a year and a half later.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So... sometime in the last half of 1941. And you say this time you discovered the nature of the treatment.

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: They had the exhaust from a diesel engine hooked up to the intake pipes. Pumping the exhaust into the room. So, I mean, I'm not stupid. Cory, sitting beside Hilde near the front of the gallery, listens with horrified fascination.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Were you given any explanation as to why the device was dismantled?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: Well... so that it could be... relocated.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And do you know where it was "relocated"? Nielson shifts uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: . Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Of course you do. They sent you along with it, didn't they, to put it back together on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: (pause) I was only a plumber. I only did what they told me.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Herr Nielson, would you please tell the court where the device was moved? Nielson shakes his head, mute.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: The witness is instructed to answer the question.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Where was the device moved?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: (finally) East.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: East. Where in the East?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: Poland.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Southern Poland?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: Southern Poland, correct.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Where, exactly, in southern Poland? Nielson doesn't want to answer. Nielson's

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Auschwitz? hand covers his face. Peter almost shouts: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Was the device moved to Auschwitz?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: (barely audible) Yes. A charge goes through the room.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: When this device was reinstalled at Auschwitz, what modifications did you make?

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (powerfully) Your testimony is that you dismantled this device ina German medical facility -- and then reassembled it without modification at the Auschwitz extermination camp in Poland?!

dialogues.speaker: NIELSON
dialogues.text: (a cry)

dialogues.speaker: I_DID WHAT THE DOCTORS TOLD ME
dialogues.text: On Mengele's face a crooked smile appears. Peter turns to the bench.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Nothing further. His eyes meet Cory's. What in God's name has he done?

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: MOVE WITH Peter as he pushes out the front door and into a chaos of protest. Police fight to contain enraged demonstrators as Peter makes his dash toward Hillmann's waiting car. An OLD MAN strains through the police ine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, HE KILLED MY BROTHERS --
dialogues.text: The Old Man is pushed back. A group of rainbow-haired punks breaks through and surrounds Peter, one of them dousing Peter with red paint. Police surge in. Peter is knocked to the ground, his briefcase torn from his grasp. He scrambles after it, paint dripping into his eyes. Strong arms reach through the melee, pull Peter to his feet. Pressing the briefcase into his hands, they hustle him toward Hillmann's car. Once at the car, Peter wipes paint out of his eyes, gets a look at his saviors: a trio of buzz-cut young FASCISTS in tattoos and jackboots. One of them shoots him a grinning Nazi salute.

dialogues.speaker: FASCIST THUG
dialogues.text: Sieg heil. Peter jerks free and leaps back as if froma rattlesnake. Fixing them with a look of absolute contempt, he ducks into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the back door still hanging open, Hillmann tries desperately to pull into traffic.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Go, Felix, go!

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'm okay -- He pulls the door closed and falls back against the seat. The skinheads pace the car like an honor guard from hell. Cory clutches Peter and screams at Hillmann:

dialogues.speaker: GO
