dialogues.text: Finding a hole in traffic, he accelerates and the skinheads fall away, hooting their support.

dialogues.speaker: BLOOD-RED WATER
dialogues.text: swirls down the drain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter showers, scrubbing paint out of his hair, his ears, his eyes, strangely buoyed by this day. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don't know which scared Felix more, those animals outside his window or me, dripping paint on his rented upholstery. "But -- but -- but, Peter -- my deposit!" Peter laughs. But soon realizes he's laughing alone.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Cory? He peels back the shower curtain. She sits with head bowed, face averted. Crying. Peter wraps a towel around himself and steps out of the shower.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What? She looks up, eyes wet with tears.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: When I saw you coming toward the car -- I thought it was blood. I thought they were killing you. Peter takes her in his arms. She sags against him. They hold onto one another. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Why did you leave? She wipes her tears with his towel. Tries to find the words.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: He kept talking about us. About our doctors, our time. Like he was pointing his finger saying you do the same things, you're as guilty as me. I wanted to prove him wrong.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Did you? Not an easy question for her to answer.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I didn't find anyone gassing Jews. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat ) I met doctors who explained why it's sometimes necessary to kill. I met one who calls herself a "helper of death." I heard a world of good intentions. And I kept thinking about your mother. And all those children at Wuerzbach. (then) What does that make those doctors? A bunch of little Mengeles?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Then what? They sit in silence, wrestling with the impossible question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter listens as Cory replays a recording.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: An active medical role, meaning...

dialogues.speaker: INTERN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Humane methods have been developed.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Are you telling me you've taken action to bring about a patient's death?

dialogues.speaker: INTERN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We're talking about patients whose lives are essentially over. Their bodies just don't know it.

dialogues.speaker: CORY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Patients who are really... dead already.

dialogues.speaker: INTERN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That's well put. She clicks off the recorder. Peter's thinking. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Uncertain exactly how to make the pieces fit. He eases back onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: When my mother told me to be careful, that what happened to Erik's uncle could happen to anyone, I was terrified. Because I didn't know how to be careful. I didn't know what to watch for. (beat ) The Jews say "Never again." But if we're only guarding against swastikas and psychotics, I'm afraid we're going to miss it. We're going to miss it. Because I don't think that's the way it happens. (so quietly) But how does it happen? Cory looks at the tapes spread in front of her. A new assurance.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: I can't tell you what all this means, Peter, but there's something here. (right at him) And I think I have an idea how our neighbors became killers. (so simple) Just a little bit at a time. Peter's face. A stone has dropped into a still pond. A switch has been thrown. A Gestalt moment. Understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The courtroom is packed and silent, all eyes focused on Peter who stands before the bench, holding in his upraised hand a book.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: One small step. (beat ) At the time of the war, German doctors held a common belief in an idea introduced by this book -- The Permission to Destroy Life Unworthy of Life. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They believed that not all lives were worth living, that in some instances physicians were in fact obligated to take life rather than save it. It's a simple idea, easily understood. It goes like this. Mengele's in the wheelchair again. His breathing is labored but he sits ramrod straight, held in place by pride and defiance.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Imagine you're a doctor, and imagine you have a patient, a 95- year-old woman within a week of death from bone cancer. Now this is an extremely painful disease, the bones become so weak that the simple act of rolling over in bed can break them. And even as you prepare an injection of morphine, you know it won't be enough to numb her horrible pain. Yet to increase the dosage will kill er. Mengele listens intently.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You explain this to your patient, and she looks you right in the eye and begs you: Fill the syringe. (beat ) Such a simple step, this step from healer to killer. Just fill the syringe. (holds up book) This book urged doctors to take that step. And why not? On what grounds could a compassionate physician refuse this woman's request? (beat ) One small step. If you read the papers, you know it's a step doctors now take every day. Mengele smiles a small smile of appreciation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Now imagine the same patient making the same request a month earlier -- before her pain has become so horrible. You know very well what's coming, and she asks you to fill the syringe. What then? Will you deny the request simply because the patient hasn't suffered sufficiently? On what grounds?... So. Another step. The Judges listen stoically.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Now imagine that instead of 95, the patient is only 75. But still suffering and just as surely doomed to die. Imagine this patient begging you to fill the syringe... Having granted the first two requests, on what grounds can you deny this one? One more step. (pause) Now what if, instead of 75, the patient is only 55?... Or 457... What if she's 35? Still suffering, still dying, still begging. (beat ) What if she's only 5? (quickly) But of course that's different. Now she can't make the request herself. So imagine her mother and father with broken hearts begging you, "Please, Doctor. End this nightmare. Fill the syringe." Peter's delivery holds the courtroom at rapt attention.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Will you deny them -- and force the suffering to continue -- simply because the patient is too young to make the request herself? On what grounds?... One more step. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (long beat) And now, finally, imagine your country at war. And imagine a child facing gruesome suffering and inescapable death. Only now, because of the war, no parent is there to make the request. And, again because of the war, it's no longer one child but a hundred children. And they're not ina hospital bed, they're in the back of a dump truck. Not your fault; the war's fault. And you have no morphine... only a burning pit. (waits) What now. WHAT NOW?! You're a doctor. On what grounds will you deny these children the same kindness, the same compassion, the same release, granted the others? (picks up book) But of course you're not doctors. You're judges. And so I ask you -- (brandishes book; thunders) If _we grant any doctor that first small step, on what grounds can we deny Doctor Mengele the last?

dialogues.speaker: ON WHAT GROUNDS
dialogues.text: (barely more than a whisper) The road to Auschwitz isn't so hard --as long as it's taken one step at a time. Cory's sober as death. Mengele glows. Peter stands his ground in the center of the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dark, quiet hours before morning, Peter walks alone through the streets of this city so visibly haunted by its past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damaged children sleep. Peter walks among them. Soaking them in. Forming a bond.  121.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments before the sun breaks the horizon. A light rain falls as a taxi moves through the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi rolls past a handful of anti-Nazi demonstrators who brave the rain to man a strategic location near the main entrance. They pay no attention to the taxi as it rounds the side of the building. Peter steps from the taxi, unfurls an umbrella and moves toward a side entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter descends at a leisurely pace, a man finally at peace with himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is frisked. His briefcase is searched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It resembles a modern ICU. A male NURSE in hospital blues sits attentively at the foot of the bed, watching a video display of the patient's vital signs and making notes in his chart. Mengele lies beneath a HISSING OXYGEN MASK, eyes closed in restless slumber. Two GUARDS stand watch as Peter steps to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Doctor. The Nurse shakes his patient, flips on lights.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Wake up, Doctor. You have a visitor. Mengele cracks his eyes open, speaks thickly.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Peter?... What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Just before six. Mengele coughs tightly into the mask. His condition appears to have worsened dramatically.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The court clerk woke me 30 minutes ago. There's going to be a verdict. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Despite his illness, Mengele speaks with a kind of happiness.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: The verdict -- (coughs again) The verdict makes no difference. I said what I came to say. (then) That's victory enough. A spasm of painful, ineffectual coughing ensues. Peter turns to the Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Can't you give him something? The question sounds motivated by something less than sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Tylenol. Aspirin.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Aspirin?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: He refuses morphine. It dulls his mind.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: So does the pain. Give it to him.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: (between coughs) I don't want it.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: A partial dose then.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: No -- But the Nurse crosses to a medicine locker.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: It may relax your airways, Doctor, help you to breathe. The Nurse opens the locker and removes a glass vial. Using a syringe, he withdraws a small quantity of the drug. Peter watches with interest. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (to Nurse) How long has he had this pain?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: It's much worse since yesterday. The tumors have begun obstructing his airways.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Can anything be done?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (holds up syringe) At this point, the best we can do is manage the pain. He crosses back to the bedside, sterilizes a port in the Iv line and inserts the needle. Mengele swats at the syringe.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: I don't need it.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I'm only giving you 40 milligrams. You're written for 100. The Nurse pushes the morphine into the line.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: It's in. The Nurse withdraws the needle and discards the syringe in a waste container. Peter turns to the Guards.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'd like to speak with my client privately. Will you give us a moment? He answers their reluctance with a reassuring smile.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I don't think I'll be in any danger. The Nurse jots a final notation in the chart and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Don't be long. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Nurse and Guards exit, leaving Peter alone with Mengele. The morphine has done its work. The old man relaxes. His eyes find Peter.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Do you know you're the only one who's bothered to visit me here? (beat ) Mueller went to my family. They told him they don't know who I am. Peter has moved to the cell door and glances through the small window into the corridor. He pulls the oxygen mask away.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: You've done well, Peter. (and) You saved your family. Peter crosses away from the door and OUT OF FRAME as Mengele lies back on his pillow.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It must be a very great burden. In prison, in pain, alone. Without hope of recovery. Though these words are delivered without any particular feeling, Mengele finds comfort in them.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You've led a difficult, lonely life. Mengele relaxes into his pillow.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And now death is imminent. As Mengele contemplates these thoughts, his eyes drift closed.

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: When it comes, you'll no doubt welcome it as you always have... a merciful release. Mengele's eyes open. Something troubling about that last remark. He turns to see:  125.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: bent over the medicine locker.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Peter turns. He's drawing fluid from a glass vial.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Filling the syringe. Mengele's stunned.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Are you going to murder me?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Murder you? No. I'm just going to... practice medicine without a license. Mengele's incredulity gives way to a crooked smile. He laughs at Peter's wicked, wicked joke. Peter withdraws the needle from the vial and crosses to locate the port in the IV line. Mengele's laughter dies.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Peter -- put that thing away before someone sees you and thinks you're serious. But Peter's dead serious. He inserts the needle in the line. Mengele claps his hands over Peter's.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: You know if you push that dose you'll spend the rest of your life in prison -- Peter allows himself the tiniest of smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: But I'm not going to push it. He grasps Mengele's hands, forces them around the syringe, and then clamps his own hands over Mengele's.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (ice) You are. Peter leans close with uncensored fury. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You ordered a truckload of living, breathing children thrown into an inferno. You mutilated, you gassed, you starved, you dissected children alive. Then you twisted the words around and around to make murder sound like a kindness. But it was no kindness. The truth is in the piles of emaciated corpses. The truth is in the mass graves. The truth is in the smoke that rose over Auschwitz. Peter exerts dangerously increased pressure against Mengele's hands. Mengele trembles as he resists.

dialogues.speaker: FOUR HUNDRED THOUSAND HUMAN
dialogues.text: BEINGS. Don't you dare deny yourself the same kindness you heaped on so many others. The Guard calls from outside:

dialogues.speaker: GUARD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Counselor? Mengele's eyes fly to the door. He rasps:

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Guard -- But Peter drowns out the feeble cry with a sharp:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Privacy, Sergeant -- please! Peter watches the cell door. When it doesn't open, he turns back to Mengele for:

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Push it, Butcher! Go on!!! PUSH

dialogues.speaker: IT
dialogues.text: And just when it seems Mengele's strength is about to fail, Peter releases his wildly shaking hands and takes a quick step back, leaving the defendant holding the syringe alone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (quietly) Push the syringe and complete your victory. Or call for the guard... and live a few more days. (wait ) Knowing the truth about yourself. Mengele gasps for breath, quaking as he stares at the deadly syringe, paralyzed by Peter's challenge. His hands tighten on the syringe. An interminable moment of tortured indecision. And then the terror becomes too great and he jerks the needle free and casts it from him. It skitters across the floor, coming to rest at Peter's feet.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: (croaks it out) Nurse -- Mengele gropes for the oxygen mask. Peter picks up the syringe. He calmly drops it in the medical waste container as Guards appear. Mengele looks from Peter to the returning Guards to the container holding the syringe. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Get the nurse in here to fix this mask. I can't breathe. The Nurse goes to work checking the flow of oxygen to the mask. Peter steps to the cell door.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: You think I was a bad doctor because I killed.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You weren't a bad doctor. (wait ) You were no doctor at all. And with that Peter goes, leaving Mengele, to sink into his pillow as the Nurse straps the mask firmly over his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAIN POUNDS the pavement. Beneath the downpour umbrellas converge on the great building.  128.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is packed and silent as the judges enter. Mengele is scarcely visible inside the glass enclosure, now stuffed almost beyond capacity with medical machinery. Even in the short time since Peter left him, his condition has deteriorated. But more than that, something has changed in Mengele, as if the corner of a carefully-placed veil has fallen away. From behind it peers a profoundly dark and frigid soul, full of venom.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: Back on the record in the matter of Germany versus Mengele. Hillmann shifts nervously. Peter is at ease.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: The defense has asked this court how it can condemn killing by one physician while sanctioning killing by others. They have asked how we may, in their words, reject the last step while welcoming the first. These questions puzzle the court. For German law sanctions killing by no one. We acknowledge that the practice of medicine -- particularly modern medicine -- poses thorny ethical dilemmas. But we declare with the laws and constitution of Germany this one simple edict: Don't kill. (and again) Don't kill. Mengele's eyes darken with blistering contempt.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: By his own admission, the defendant did kill -- prolifically, energetically and without remorse. In the name of science he undertook barbaric experiments that inflicted unimaginable suffering. And then he congratulated himself with words like kindness, mercy and compassion. Cory listens from the gallery. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE
dialogues.text: This court instructs the defendant that genuine compassion addresses human suffering by drawing alongside the sufferer to comfort and to serve. (with great force) It does not annihilate him. (beat) The defendant did successfully establish one fact beyond dispute: The human heart is capable of justifying any evil it craves. And so the judgment of this court is as follows:

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE'S FACE
dialogues.text: is set.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: As to the charges of war crimes, guilty on all counts. Mengele doesn't blink. PUSH IN.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: As to the charges of crimes against minorities, guilty on all counts. PUSH CLOSER.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: As to the charges of crimes against humanity, guilty on all counts. CONTINUE PUSH INTO EXTREME CLOSEUP.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDING JUDGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Because of the hideous nature of these crimes and the enthusiasm with which they were committed, this court will mete out the maximum penalty possible under German law: life in prison. (gavels) This matter is concluded. Mengele breathes a single word, a lifetime of rage distilled in a whisper:

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: Idiots.  130.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COURTROOM
dialogues.text: Silence prevails. The Judges rise and sweep from the room. Cory sits motionless. Slowly and with little sound, spectators rise and move toward the exit. Peter gazes into the glass enclosure as a retinue of earnest young doctors surrounds Mengele and prepares to move him. Hillmann steps to Peter's side.

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: Life in prison. (bitterly) He'll laugh all the way to the grave.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Do you believe in hell, Felix?

dialogues.speaker: HILLMANN
dialogues.text: I don't know. Do you? Peter never takes his eyes off Mengele.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I'm hoping. They watch as Mengele is wheeled from the enclosure. The attendants pause to reposition the oxygen tank and Mengele's eyes meet Peter's. His voice is a hoarse whisper.

dialogues.speaker: MENGELE
dialogues.text: We'd have done better with a medical tribunal. (agonizing cough) These imbeciles... (another cough) These imbeciles have no idea what's happening in medicine today. The attendants roll Mengele slowly away. Peter watches until he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the crush of courtgoers exiting the building, Cory searches for Peter. She spots him near the doors, standing still. Like someone going into shock following a trauma. Cory crosses to him. He turns to her. Their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: This morning... I had the chance to kill him. I almost did it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Cory looks through the doors to the waiting mob of reporters and beyond them the crowds of protestors.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Tell them that. Make them understand why you did all this. Even if it means never arguing another case. Tell them.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No. I have to do something harder. He takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter and Cory emerge together, raising an umbrella against the rain that falls in sheets. Reporters thunder questions. Peter steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What can I tell you? That Josef Mengele was a savage butcher? Of course he was. But you already know that. What can I tell you? That no connection exists between Germany's first well-intentioned killing and the bloodbath that followed? But it does exist. We proved that. Josef Mengele thinks this fact excuses him. He's wrong. (wait ) I fear it indicts us all. (wait again) What can I tell you to help you sleep tonight? Only this. Cherish life. Peter's eyes turn to Cory and he pulls her to him.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Cherish. Every. Life. Peter steps away from the microphones. A WAGNERIAN ARIA BEGINS. Cory takes the umbrella from him. Lowers it. Taking his hand, she walks with him, pushing through the reporters, solemnly and unprotected, into the drenching rain. FADE OUT.  132.

dialogues.speaker: A HEAVILY-SHADOWED, UNIDENTIFIABLE, OTHER-WORLDLY PLACE
dialogues.text: The ARIA is joined by a stark HISS. Something dark glides INTO FRAME. Gleaming black boots. Prone. Followed by the crisp trousers of an SS officer's uniform. Then the dark uniform tunic, arms folded precisely across the chest after the manner of the SS. And then the face. Hauptsturmfuhrer Josef Mengele. Aged and grey. Eyes wide open. They blink once. Twice. The body trollies past, before it the open mouth of a wildly HISSING GAS OVEN. As the body slides into the inferno, the trousers begin to burn. The eyes blink again. The ARIA SOARS. FADE OUT.
